abstract: PART THREE: THE TEAMS

headline: Panasonic Goes Wide With 25mm Lenses
abstract: Panasonic’s new digital cameras offer ultra-wide-angle lenses.

headline: JHL Capital Reports Gains of Up to 18%
abstract: John Paulson isn’t the only hedge fund manager to come out of 2008 with big profits. The Chicago-based JHL Capital Group, a small firm run by James H. Litinsky, chalked up gains of 17.1 percent to 18 percent net of fees last year despite the global stock market meltdown, according to a letter the firm sent to clients on Tuesday.

headline: Another View: Advice on Lawyers for Madoff Victims
abstract: Eric M. Rosenberg, an attorney and president of LitigationProofing, a firm that helps companies limit exposure to potential lawsuits, offers this view of what Bernard L. Madoff’s investors should consider when they are choosing lawyers to seek recovery of their money:

headline: New SDXC Memory Cards to Hit 2 Terabytes
abstract: New XDSC memory cards will offer 2 terabytes of storage.

headline: Adding Up A.I.G.’s Backdoor Bailouts
abstract: Of the $170 billion in government funds used to prop up American International Group, a large chunk has gone to buy soured securities — at full price — from big banks like Goldman Sachs.

headline: After Madoff, Regulatory Oversight of Auditors Is Back
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has quietly backed away from a rule that had allowed the accounting firm that audited Bernard L. Madoff Investment Securities to avoid oversight by a regulator that was created after the Enron and WorldCom scandals, The New York Times’s Floyd Norris reported.

headline: Solvency of Big Banks Is Questioned
abstract: Some of the nation’s large banks, according to economists and other finance experts, are like dead men walking, The New York Times’s Steve Lohr reports.

headline: Dr.  Doom Finds Promise in Obama’s Toxic-Asset Plan
abstract: Nouriel Roubini, a/k/a “Dr. Doom,” is giving the Obama administration’s new plan to buy toxic assets the thumbs up.

headline: From DealBook: Circuit City to Liquidate
abstract: The nation’s number-two tech retailer is seeking court approval to shut down, says our blog-cousin DealBook.

headline: Is General Electric Next?
abstract: Nobody knows for sure whether G.E. is in trouble — not even the bears who are shouting it from the rafters.

headline: Of Brawn, Button, Branson and the Virgin Pole Position
abstract: Formula One somehow, year after year, seems to write its own extraordinary, larger-than-life, wild and inspired stories. That’s why I think no one has ever made a very good novel or film – although Frankenheimer’s Grand Prix is memorable – out of the sport.

headline: Q & A: Picking a New Default Font in Word
abstract: If you share a lot of documents with other users, it is a good idea to pick a common font.

headline: Vizio and Westinghouse Want Your Help
abstract: Vizio and Westinghouse hope to get the public to support their attempt to reduce royalty payments for key digital TV patents.

headline: Seeking Obama Fashions, Visitors Crash J. Crew’s Web Site
abstract: J. Crew’s e-commerce site crashed under heavy traffic as people tried to find the clothing and accessories that Michelle Obama and her daughters wore to the inauguration.

headline: Tomorrow’s Junk, Today: A Look at Faltering Angels
abstract: Homeowners aren’t the only ones feeling the strain of too much debt: the number of companies whose debt ratings are poised to fall from investment grade to speculative grade — less euphemistically called junk — is at an 18-year high, according to data from Standard & Poor’s.

headline: Next at G.M.: a Restructuring Chief?
abstract: Even as General Motors bid goodbye to Rick Wagoner and ushered in its new chief executive, Frederick Henderson, restructuring circles were abuzz Monday with speculation that another player may soon join the carmaker: a chief restructuring officer.

headline: National Century Executive Gets 30 Years for Fraud
abstract: Nearly seven years after National Century Financial Enterprises collapsed in a $2.9 billion fraud, its founder, Lance K. Poulsen, was sentenced to 30 years in prison on Friday in one of the harshest white-collar punishments in history, The New York Times’s Zachery Kouwe reported.

headline: Video: What’s Ahead at Davos 2009
abstract: Andrew Ross Sorkin of The New York Times has touched down in Davos, Switzerland, and he gives a video briefing of what to expect from this year’s World Economic Forum.

headline: TM to Raise $1.4 Billion in Rights Offer
abstract: The Malaysian company TM International plans to raise 5.25 billion ringgit ($1.4 billion) in a rights offer to repay debt.

headline: Denny’s Becomes a Super Bowl Advertiser
abstract: Denny’s, the restaurant chain, is becoming a Super Bowl advertiser for the first time.

headline: Political Affirmative Action: Quotas for Women
abstract: Some countries have started affirmative action programs to help women get elected to public office. A group of economists recently looked at whether such quotas have been successful.

headline: A Peek Into the Value of KKR’s Investments
abstract: Most private equity firms keep the value of their investments carefully shielded from the public’s eyes. But Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the giant leveraged buyout firm, is opening up a little on Monday as one of its publicly traded affiliates reports results, The New York Times’s Michael J. de la Merced writes.

headline: Why Stocks Still Aren’t Cheap
abstract: Stocks are falling, but so are earnings. And stocks may still have some ways to fall.

headline: Major League Gaming Scores $7.5 Million
abstract: The professional video game league Major League Gaming has raised an additional $7.5 million, an addition to its second venture round from 2006, VentureBeat reported.

headline: Take Better Photos With a Fast Prime Lens
abstract: Fast prime lenses enable you to take sharper photos in lower light.

headline: Old Web Prank Links ‘Obama’ With ‘Failure’
abstract: An old Web prank linking President Bush to online searches for “miserable failure” now links to President Obama.

headline: Former Jets Punter Among 3 Indicted in a Tax Scheme
abstract: A federal grand jury in Las Vegas on Thursday indicted a former professional football player, a casino owner and a Las Vegas business associate for promoting a $278 million scheme that prosecutors contend allowed taxpayers to illegally claim disability-related tax breaks, The New York Times’s Lynnley Browning reported.

headline: G.E. Shares Touch 18-Year Low
abstract: Update | 4:21 p.m. Shares of General Electric, long considered the archetypal blue-chip stock, tumbled as much as 18 percent on Wednesday amid concerns that the industrial and financial conglomerate might lose its coveted triple-A credit rating.

headline: New UBS Chief Calls for Change to Swiss Banking Laws
abstract: The new chief executive of UBS told a newspaper on Saturday that Switzerland should consider changing its banking secrecy laws so they no longer protect suspected tax evaders.

headline: Facebook Is No Friend of Power.com
abstract: Facebook sues the start-up social networking portal for accessing its site without authorization.

headline: Can Ruth Madoff Keep the Penthouse?
abstract: Peter J. Henning, a professor at Wayne State Law School, occasionally writes as a guest blogger for The Deal Professor. Mr. Henning specializes in issues related to white-collar crime and is a former editor of the White Collar Crime Law Prof Blog.

headline: Resolution Said to Be Eyeing Prudential Unit
abstract: Clive Cowdery, the founder of the British financial buyout firm Resolution, has approached Prudential P.L.C. to assess its interest in selling its British insurance business, The Telegraph reported.

headline: New iPod Shuffle Unveiled
abstract: Apple’s new audio player gets even smaller, and now talks to you.

headline: 2 Dozen Victims Seek to Be Heard at Madoff Plea
abstract: At least 25 investors in Bernard Madoff’s failed business are asking to speak at a Thursday hearing at which Mr. Madoff is expected to plead guilty, The Associated Press reported.

headline: 10 Tips for Better St. Paddy’s Parade Photos
abstract: How to take better pictures this Tuesday. No luck required.

headline: Twittering Tips for Beginners
abstract: I’m still dubious about Twitter’s prospects for becoming a tool for ordinary people. But one thing’s for sure: The whole thing would be a lot more palatable if somebody would explain the basics.

headline: Russia to Discuss Claims With Bank of New York
abstract: Bank of New York Mellon said Tuesday that it would meet with the Russian government to discuss a settlement of a $22.5 billion lawsuit that Moscow has brought against it.

headline: The Big Three? Try the Small Many
abstract: Innovation works by having small firms compete like crazy and try out new things. That means that last thing that the government should be doing is propping up big declining firms like Detroit’s Big Three, an economist writes.

headline: How Things Change
abstract: “The I.M.F. does not have enough money for what is coming,” said Guillermo Ortiz, the governor of Mexico’s central bank.

headline: E.D.F. Takes Stake in Big Swiss Energy Firm
abstract: Electricite de France said Friday that it has agreed to buy a 25 percent stake in Switzerland’s leading energy company Alpiq Holding for about 705 million euros ($922 million), The Associated Press reported.

headline: Once Coveted, Bank Chiefs’ Jobs Have Turned Sour
abstract: Tough government overseers. Sulky shareholders. Restive colleagues. No job security. And an annual paycheck of $1.

headline: Young and in Debt
abstract: Younger families were much more leveraged than their older counterparts when the recession erupted.

headline: Dear A.I.G., I Quit!
abstract: The following is a letter sent on Tuesday by Jake DeSantis, an executive vice president of the American International Group’s financial products unit, to Edward M. Liddy, the chief executive of A.I.G. Read the full letter here.

headline: Hedge-Fund Swindler Due in Court After Checkup
abstract: Fresh from a medical exam, the former hedge fund manager Samuel Israel is returning to court on charges that he skipped out on a 20-year prison sentence, The Associated Press reported.

headline: HDMI — Do You Need It?
abstract: Determining if the latest audio-video connection worth the money.

headline: HSBC Seeks $18 Billion in New Capital and Cuts Jobs
abstract: Update | 6:47 a.m. HSBC Holdings said Monday that it would ask investors for nearly $18 billion in new capital and cut more than 6,000 jobs as it braces for more market turmoil and positions itself for possible acquisitions, The New York Times’s Julia Werdigier reports.

headline: Pressure Grows on UBS Before Senate Hearing
abstract: Documents released on Tuesday provide new evidence that the Swiss bank UBS sought ways to circumvent Internal Revenue Service rules to help wealthy Americans set up secret offshore entities and insurance plans to evade taxes on billions of dollars in assets.

headline: Fortunoff Files for Bankruptcy Again
abstract: Fortunoff, the luxury goods store chain that sold itself to the owner of Lord & Taylor last year, is again seeking bankruptcy.

headline: The Conficker Worm: April Fool’s Joke or Unthinkable Disaster?
abstract: The sophisticated Conficker worm, which has infected millions of computers worldwide, will activate on April 1. But what will it actually do?

headline: C.E.S. Interview: Casio Founder Kazuo Kashio
abstract: As far as Casio is concerned, digital cameras are not about taking pictures but about having fun.

headline: Q & A: Printing Without Wires
abstract: The easiest way to set up a printer on a wireless home network.

headline: Index Closes $438.8 Million Fund
abstract: Index Ventures has closed a $438.8 million fund to provide cash to early-stage biotechnology and clean-tech start-ups.

headline: Ratings: Modest Audience for Couric’s Grammy Special
abstract: Round two of Hollywood week on “American Idol” attracted 26.3 million viewers on Wednesday, according to Nielsen’s estimates, catapulting Fox into first place in the night’s ratings.

headline: Housing Prices Heat Map
abstract: An animated map that shows how home prices changed in each state each quarter, relative to that state’s long-term trend.

headline: British Regulator Quits as Accusations Mount in Banking Crisis
abstract: The deputy head of the watchdog agency that regulates Britain’s banks resigned hurriedly on Wednesday after he was accused of firing a whistle-blower who had warned in 2004 that Halifax Bank of Scotland, or HBOS, the fast-expanding mortgage lender both men then worked for, was accumulating levels of debt that put it at unacceptably high risk.

headline: Geithner Promotes Broader Control of Financial Firms
abstract: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner pressed his case on Wednesday for expanding the government’s ability to take over and restructure ailing institutions that threaten the broader financial system, Anahad O’Connor of The New York Times reports.

headline: Google Phone GPS Misses by a Mile
abstract: Google, so good at may things, fails to get its G1 phone’s GPS working

headline: Will the Geithner Plan Work? Part II
abstract: Nouriel Roubini offers DealBook his take on the Obama administration’s new plan to buy toxic assets.

headline: Consumers Never Had It So Good, Part II
abstract: A counterpoint to an earlier post, with research from a Harvard professor on the expenses Americans face for core household purchases, leading to higher debt obligations.

headline: For Pfizer, a Big Deal and a Test
abstract: After announcing the $68 billion megamerger with Wyeth on Monday morning, Pfizer’s chief executive, Jeffrey B. Kindler, did not have much time to celebrate.

headline: Chinalco Says It Isn’t Seeking Control of Rio Tinto
abstract: Chinalco said on Monday that it will not seek control of Rio Tinto, as it reassured Australia’s government over its planned $19.5 billion investment in the miner.

headline: Madoff-Hit Medici Says It’s Not on Verge Of Shutdown
abstract: Bank Medici of Austria, one of the biggest victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s alleged $50 billion Ponzi scheme, said Thursday it is not on the brink of shutting down and sees no reason why it should forfeit its banking license.

headline: NRDC Is Said to Drop Stake in Peter Som’s Label
abstract: At least one private equity firm is seeking to cut its exposure to the business of high fashion.

headline: Quadrant Takes Stake in Genius from Weinsteins
abstract: An affiliate of investment firm Quadrant Management has acquired a majority stake in Genius Products, the troubled home-video distributor, from the Weinstein Company.

headline: Regulators Close Banks in Georgia and California
abstract: Regulators closed FirstBank Financial Services in Georgia, and County Bank and Alliance Bank, both of California, bringing to nine the number of failures this year by federally insured banks.

headline: Freddie Mac Posts $23.9 Billion Loss; Seeks More Aid
abstract: Freddie Mac, the mortgage finance company, posted a fourth-quarter loss of $23.9 billion Wednesday and said it would ask for additional government aid of nearly $31 billion.

headline: Amid a Crisis, Davos Gets Ready
abstract: Each year, political heavyweights, big thinkers and corporate chieftans converge in the Swiss mountain town of Davos to talk about the global issues of the day. But not since 2002, when the conference was held in New York in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks, has the sense of import and urgency been so great.

headline: Britain Will Get up to 75% Stake in Lloyds
abstract: Britain’s government tightened its grip on another ailing bank, the Lloyds Banking Group, on Saturday, and pressure is mounting on Barclays and other lenders that have turned down government help to join the British Treasury’s latest effort to revive the economy

headline: The Government’s ‘Worse Case Scenario’
abstract: A look at the government’s two “stress test” scenarios.

headline: From DealBook: Circuit City to Liquidate
abstract: The nation’s number-two tech retailer is seeking court approval to shut down, says our blog-cousin DealBook.

headline: G.E. Says Finance Unit Can Weather the Storm
abstract: General Electric said Thursday that its finance arm, GE Capital, would not need more funding, even using pessimistic assumptions about where the economy is headed.

headline: Trustee Wants to Ditch Madoff’s Fleet of Luxury Autos
abstract: Call it the Bernard L. Madoff Collection of Fine Cars.

headline: British Tobacco Chairman to Chair Rio Tinto, Too
abstract: The mining group Rio Tinto has appointed Jan du Plessis, the chairman of British American Tobacco, to head its board as well, the company said on Tuesday.

headline: Video: Blair on Gaza and the Financial Crisis
abstract: Blair warned against economic protectionism in the interview, especially in the relationship between the United States and China.

headline: Banking Bosses Go to Washington
abstract: Lloyd Blankfein of Goldman Sachs, James Dimon of JPMorgan Chase, Kenneth Lewis of Bank of America and Vikram Pandit of Citigroup are among the banking chiefs expected to head to Washington on Friday, where they will meet with President Barack Obama and, most likely, hear him pitch his administration’s plan to repair the nation’s financial system.

headline: Senate Committee Endorses Geithner for Treasury
abstract: Updated at 6:15 p.m.

headline: Ratings: The Top 13 on ‘Idol’
abstract: The top 13 finalists on “American Idol” performed songs by Michael Jackson on Tuesday, attracting the night’s largest television audience with 25.2 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The two-hour “Idol” episode lifted Fox far ahead of its network rivals in the ratings.

headline: French Lawmakers Hope to Inspire Linux Revolution
abstract: The French government says its embrace of Linux over Windows will help the French economy.

headline: Redpoint Embraces Cleantech With C.T.O. Hire
abstract: Redpoint Ventures is showing the love for clean tech by hiring Nety Krishna to serve as the chief technology officer of its energy and materials practice, a newly created position.

headline: Modest Start to Fed Plan to Aid Sale of Securities
abstract: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said on Thursday that it would lend investors $4.7 billion next week in the first installment of a highly anticipated program intended to help revive lending to consumers and businesses.

headline: Would Bankruptcy Be More Costly for G.M.?
abstract: Businesses filing for bankruptcy need loans to work out their troubles, or face liquidation.

headline: Six Flavors of Windows 7
abstract: Microsoft details the different versions of Windows 7 coming later this year.

headline: Centaurus Pitches Low-Fee Fund, Report Says
abstract: London-based Centaurus Capital, following some rivals, is starting a low-fee, back-to-basics fund, as the troubled hedge fund continues to unwind its flagship Alpha fund, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Santander Sweetens Deal For Madoff Clients, Report Says
abstract: Banco Santander , Spain’s biggest bank, has quietly improved a deal to compensate selected private banking clients who lost money to accused swindler Bernard L. Madoff, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Intel Capital Invests $23 Million in India
abstract: Intel Capital, the investment arm of Intel, said Wednesday that it will invest $23 million in three Indian companies in areas ranging from online marketing to education.

headline: App of the Week, Now in 3-D
abstract: The App of the Week lets you create 3-D photos with an iPhone.

headline: Boxee Brings Hulu Back to Its Service
abstract: Boxee, which brings Internet video to television screens, introduces a way for users to sidestep objections from the broadcast networks that own Hulu.com.

headline: Arrington of TechCrunch Goes on Hiatus
abstract: From Jenna Wortham at Bits:

headline: Bracing for a Bailout Backlash
abstract: The Obama administration is increasingly concerned about a populist backlash against banks and Wall Street, worried that anger at financial institutions could also end up being directed at Congress and the White House and could complicate President Obama’s agenda, according to The New York Times’s Adam Nagourney.

headline: Investors Testify at Indiana Adviser’s Hearing
abstract: An Indiana financial adviser accused of trying to fake his death in a plane crash improperly moved money from accounts, forged signatures on investment documents and charged exorbitant fees, investors testified at a hearing.

headline: 2 Restructuring Lawyers Jump Shops
abstract: As the economy and the still-mostly-stuck credit markets continue to batter companies, law firms are stocking up on their restructuring practices. And that means that more lawyers are jumping to rival firms.

headline: Home Dumping Out West
abstract: Home sales rise in the west. Is that a sign of more foreclosures?

headline: Brains or brawn for Brawn?
abstract: The team that was Honda and is now Brawn has dominated the news all winter. If budgets were decided on PR coups, then this team would certainly be at the top of the heap over the winter.

headline: A Milestone for Working Women?
abstract: Is it possible that one legacy of this recession is that women become a majority of the workforce for the first time in American history? an economist writes.

headline: Lehman Brothers Spins Off V.C. Firm
abstract: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

headline: Facebook Tries to Become a Democracy
abstract: A week after users forced Facebook to withdraw changes to its terms of service, the company said it would solicit comments and in some cases votes from users on all proposed policy changes.

headline: Enzon Takes Fire From Another Activist
abstract: Enzon Pharmaceuticals, a drug company which has been under pressure from shareholders like billionaire Carl C. Icahn for nearly a year, is facing demands from another investor to immediately install two directors to its board and fire Goldman Sachs as its financial advisor.

headline: Gutierrez and Tambay now teammates
abstract: In my last blog post I linked to the story I did last week about the rising talents of the younger generations. (Actually, they’re ALL so young now, right up and into F1!) Among others, I mentioned specifically Esteban Gutierrez and Adrien Tambay from the European Formula BMW series, which the Mexican won and the Frenchman finished third in.

headline: HBO to Televise Inaugural Opener
abstract: HBO will be the exclusive broadcaster of an “opening celebration” on Sunday, Jan. 18, two days before Barack Obama’s inauguration.

headline: Sirius XM Shares Rise on News of Refinancing Efforts
abstract: Sirius XM Satellite Radio said Friday that it had refinanced about $172.5 million in outstanding bonds, but that it might be forced to file for bankruptcy by Tuesday if it cannot make further headway in negotiations with its creditors.

headline: Googling Your Home Electricity Usage
abstract: Google hopes the early announcement of its PowerMeter will help its product and advocacy efforts around energy reform.

headline: Harvard Sells Off Many U.S. Stocks
abstract: Harvard University’s endowment cut 67 percent of its holdings in United States stocks in the fourth quarter, amid big losses in equity markets.

headline: T-Mobile’s New Phone Lineup at C.E.S.
abstract: T-Mobile has unveiled its new line of phones at C.E.S., including the popular BlackBerry Curve.

headline: Inaugurating Social TV
abstract: On CNN.com, watch the inauguration while seeing what your Facebook friends are saying about it.

headline: Blackstone Said to Reject Disclosure Request
abstract: The Blackstone Group, the world’s largest publicly listed private-equity firm, rejected a request from the Securities and Exchange Commission to disclose the performance of its buyout and hedge funds in its financial reports, Bloomberg News reported, citing letters the regulator released earlier this month.

headline: Satyam Sale Kicks Off
abstract: India’s  Satyam Computer Services, which has been struck by fraud, closes registrations for potential bidders on Thursday, starting a process to sell a majority stake in the company caught in the country’s biggest corporate scandal, Reuters reported.

headline: Cuomo Says Most Huge A.I.G. Bonuses Were Returned
abstract: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York announced late Monday afternoon that 9 of the top 10 bonus recipients at the American International Group were giving back their bonuses.

headline: Philanthropy Amid a Global Crisis
abstract: The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation said it would contribute $34 million to fight a family of neglected tropical diseases that kill or lame millions of people.

headline: Wozniak Accepts Post at a Storage Start-Up
abstract: Steve Wozniak, the co-founder of Apple, could ignore the call of the motherboard no longer. He is going back to work — this time at Fusion-io, a start-up company that tweaks computers to let them tap vast amounts of storage at very quick rates.

headline: Mozilla Spends Money to Make Web Video Free
abstract: The foundation behind Firefox hopes $100,000 will build a free online video format to rival software from Microsoft and Adobe.

headline: A Total Ban on Dialing and Driving?
abstract: A safety group has proposed a total national ban on using a cellphone while driving, saying hands free sets are no safer then handsets.

headline: Foursquare Seeks to Turn Nightlife Into a Game
abstract: Former Googler Dennis Crowley unveiled Foursquare, a location-based mobile application that awards points for pub crawling and other activities, at the South by Southwest festival.

headline: From Shock to Action
abstract: From shock to action. How companies deal with strucural change.

headline: ‘Black Swan’ Author Sees Trouble Exceeding 1930s
abstract: The author of “The Black Swan,” Nassim Nicholas Taleb, predicts that the global financial crisis will be harder to end than the Great Depression and it may force the United States government to nationalize some banks.

headline: BofA, Wells Employees Were Aboard Crashed Plane
abstract: What was perhaps the most riveting story in New York on Thursday afternoon had almost nothing to do with finance: a US Airways plane that plunged into the Hudson River on the West Side of Manhattan.

headline: Who Needs a College Reunion? I’ve Got Facebook
abstract: Have social networking sites like Facebook rendered college reunions obsolete?

headline: Ross and Carlyle Mull Joint Bid for BankUnited, Report Says
abstract: Wilbur Ross and the Carlyle Group are mulling a joint bid BankUnited Financial, a struggling Florida-based bank with $14 billion in assets, The Financial Times reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: Administration Seeks Increase in Oversight of Executive Pay
abstract: The Obama administration will call for increased oversight of executive pay at all banks, Wall Street firms and possibly other companies as part of a sweeping plan to overhaul financial regulation, The New York Times reported, citing government officials.

headline: When Hedge Funds High-Flyers Crash
abstract: Not that long ago, hedge fund managers oozed money and power, snapping up contemporary art like chewing gum and basking in attention from investors eager to part with their cash.

headline: A Pirated Fount of Free TV
abstract: Because of widely available broadband access and a new wave of streaming sites, it has become surprisingly easy to watch pirated video online.

headline: The Case for Small-Government Egalitarianism
abstract: An economist writes that the stimulus debate badly needs the voices of that now-rare breed: Andrew Jackson’s intellectual descendant, the small-government egalitarian.

headline: Pioneer Said to Open Talks on Car Electronics Deal
abstract: Pioneer is in talks with Mitsubishi Electric, Alpine Electronics and Clarion on a possible tie-up in car navigation and other auto equipment operations, the Nikkei business daily reported on Sunday, according to Reuters.

headline: Small Software Makers Ripe For Takeovers, Report Says
abstract: Some smaller software companies may be compelling acquisition targets, despite depressed stock valuations in the sector, Barron’s reported in its March 16 edition.

headline: Ratings: ‘Lost’ Sees Highest Ratings of the Season
abstract: ABC’s “Lost” delivered its highest ratings of the season on Wednesday, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: The Couch Potato’s Dream
abstract: A new home automation system from Lutron cuts cost by half, but it is still a lot of money to automate your home.

headline: YouTube and Universal Music Said to Discuss Deal
abstract: Google‘s YouTube and the Universal Music Group, the world’s largest music label, are in advanced discussions over a licensing agreement that could lead to the creation of a premium site for music videos, The New York Times’s Miguel Helft reported, citing a person briefed on the talks.

headline: Markets Rebound From Morning Fall
abstract: Despite a rout in financial stocks, Wall Street fought back from early losses to close slightly higher on Thursday, even as economic reports sent up more distress flares about the widening recession, The New York Times’s Jack Healy reported.

headline: Roche Wins Battle for Genentech
abstract: Roche, the Swiss drugmaker, has struck a deal with Genentech to acquire all outstanding shares in the American biotech group for $46.8 billion, the two companies said Thursday.

headline: Medpedia: A Collaborative Encyclopedia for Health Care
abstract: From Jenna Wortham at Bits:

headline: Merger Expected of Ticketmaster and Live Nation
abstract: Ticketmaster is expected to announce on Monday an agreement to merge with Live Nation in a deal that could reshape the music and live entertainment business, The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin reports.

headline: Dr.  Doom Finds Promise in Obama’s Toxic-Asset Plan
abstract: Nouriel Roubini, a/k/a “Dr. Doom,” is giving the Obama administration’s new plan to buy toxic assets the thumbs up.

headline: From DealBook: Circuit City to Liquidate
abstract: The nation’s number-two tech retailer is seeking court approval to shut down, says our blog-cousin DealBook.

headline: Economic Humor: No Longer an Oxymoron
abstract: Notes from the “humor session” at the annual American Economic Association conference.

headline: BofA Withdraws Job Offers to Foreign M.B.A. Students
abstract: Bank of America has become the first U.S. bank to withdraw job offers made to foreign M.B.A. students graduating from U.S. business schools this summer, according to The Financial Times.

headline: Cerberus-Owned Aozora Bank Shows Loss, Replaces Chief
abstract: Aozora Bank warned on Tuesday that its annual net loss would widen to $2.1 billion, and it replaced its chief executive as it aims to forge a less risky strategy focused on commercial lending in Japan, Reuters reported.

headline: Nacchio Asks to Remain Free Pending Court Review
abstract: A lawyer for Qwest‘s former chief, Joseph Nacchio, is asking a Federal District Court to let Mr. Nacchio remain free while he challenges his insider-trading conviction, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Roche Chairman Said Confident in Genentech Bid
abstract: Swiss drugmaker Roche is confident that it will succeed in its bid for U.S. biotechnology group Genentech, the Swiss drugmaker’s chairman was quoted as saying in comments released on Saturday, according to Reuters.

headline: At Super Return, Hope Amid the Gloom
abstract: Wednesday at the Super Return private equity conference in Berlin brought discussions about hedge funds, unions and why, despite what may be a shakeout ahead, there is reason to be optimistic.

headline: KKR Financial Takes $1.2 Billion Quarterly Loss
abstract: KKR Financial Holdings, a debt fund managed by private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, reported a $1.2 billion quarterly loss on Monday and said it would not pay a dividend for the fourth quarter, and probably not for 2009.

headline: Seeking Jail, U.S. Argues Madoff Can’t Be Trusted
abstract: We don’t trust you, Bernie.

headline: Snow Skills: Getting the White Right
abstract: Tips on how to take the best photos in snowy conditions.

headline: Banks Feud Over Sure-Fire Bet That Failed
abstract: Nearly two years ago, on a Tuesday in February 2007, a Wall Street salesman pitched an investment that sounded almost magical. It was called Gemstone VII. A shiny amalgam of financial instruments, it promised attractive returns — with virtually no risk.

headline: AT&T Learns From Mom in Fighting File Sharing
abstract: AT&T learns from Mom: nagging with no punishment is an effective way to stop customers from trading music or movie files.

headline: Clear Channel Plans to Cut 1,850 Jobs
abstract: The parent company of Clear Channel Communications, struggling in the advertising downturn, announced on Tuesday that it was eliminating 1,850 positions, or about 9 percent of its staff, The New York Times’s Stephanie Clifford reported. The dismissals were effective immediately.

headline: An Anchor Job With Only 9 Hours’ Notice
abstract: Last October, with only nine hours’ notice, Jane Velez-Mitchell joined the ranks of evening cable news anchors.

headline: 2009’s First Month Disappoints Investors
abstract: The stock market fell for a fourth consecutive week on poor earnings reports and on data showing that the economy contracted in the fourth quarter at the fastest pace in a quarter-century.

headline: Merck and Schering-Plough’s Extreme Engineering
abstract: Merck filed the agreement for its acquisition of Schering-Plough with regulators on Tuesday. The agreement has many interesting provisions throughout, but I want to focus on the two most important items.

headline: Nearly 800 Jobs Axed at Delphi’s Steering Division
abstract: Nearly 800 jobs are being eliminated at  Delphi‘s steering division, which is bring sold to private equity firm Platinum Equity.

headline: Publication Names Lazard as Bank of the Year
abstract: Barclays Capital‘s Bob Diamond was chosen as banker of the year by Investment Dealers’ Digest, which also picked Lazard as its bank of the year.

headline: New Affordable Cameras, Just for Kids
abstract: Digital Blue is expanding its Snap line of inexpensive cameras for kids.

headline: Geithner Seeks ‘New Rules of the Game’ on Wall St.

headline: Bank of the Future: More Like a Utility or a Drug Company?
abstract: “We can’t be like utilities — we are closer to the pharmaceutical industry,” suggested Alessandro Profumo, the CEO of UniCredit Group in Italy.

headline: Suspect in Ponzi Scheme Surrenders on Long Island
abstract: A New York businessman sought by federal authorities in connection with a suspected $380 million Ponzi scheme has been arrested and charged with one count of mail fraud.

headline: Pfizer Said to Be on the Lookout for Takeover Targets
abstract: Pfizer, the world’s biggest pharmaceutical group, is open to to doing some dealmaking, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Fed Sees Pushback in Effort to Expand Authority
abstract: As the Federal Reserve seeks to expand its role as a financial stability regulator, Congress is beginning to push back.

abstract: More than 400 television stations have stopped broadcasting in old-fashioned analog form, according to the Federal Communications Commission, months before the rescheduled transition to digital TV.

headline: Lazard Shares Up as Profit Tumbles
abstract: It must seem like yet another crazy day on Wall Street when an investment bank reports that its quarterly profits fell by half — and its stock jumps 10 percent. But that is what happened to Lazard on Wednesday.

headline: RBS Posts Biggest Loss in British Corporate History
abstract: Reporting the biggest annual loss in British corporate history, the Royal Bank of Scotland on Thursday became the first bank to sign up for the British government’s asset protection plan, meant to repair the economy and revive lending by helping banks to set aside illiquid assets, The New York Times’s Julia Werdigier reported.

headline: T.C.I. Dumps Indian Bank Holdings, Report Says
abstract: The Children’s Investment Fund, the activist hedge fund with $9.5 billion under management, has dumped its holdings in Indian state-owned banks in one of the biggest single sales by a foreign institutional investor in the country’s stock market, The Financial Times reported.

headline: TD Ameritrade to Buy Thinkorswim for $606 Million
abstract: TD Ameritrade said Thursday that it was buying thinkorswim for about $606 million in cash and stock, solidifying TD Ameritrade’s standing as one of the largest online brokerage firms.

headline: So Many iPhone Apps, So Little Time
abstract: There are now 15,000 programs available on the App Store, and so many more are flooding in that Apple’s army of screeners can’t even keep up.

headline: HSBC: A Harbinger of Things to Come in Asia?
abstract: When HSBC reports its 2008 results on Monday, it could offer a glimpse into the future of the economic downturn in Asia, The Wall Street Journal says.

headline: Cell Networks Survive Inaugural Crush
abstract: Despite the legions of cellphone sharers, Washington’s cellphone networks appeared to be holding up.

headline: A talk with Max
abstract: I attended Max Mosley’s annual pre-season get together with a few members of the press yesterday in London and did a story about the talk with Mosley it that we’ve just put on the site and which is coming out in tomorrow’s IHT.

headline: Offerpal Media Raises $15 Million to Peddle In-Game Ads

headline: Get Ready for an New and Improved JPEG
abstract: A new and improved JPEG format is expected to be available later this year.

abstract: A New York hedge fund is calling on Chemed, which owns Vitas and Roto-Rooter, to spin off one its operating units with a view to potentially selling one or both.

headline: S.E.C. Charges Missing Fund Manager With Fraud
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged a missing hedge fund manager with fraud on Wednesday, saying he misled investors and overstated the value of investments in six of his funds by at least $300 million.

headline: Blockbuster Links With CinemaNow for Video Delivery
abstract: Blockbuster is stamping its brand on CinemaNow‘s system for delivering movies over the Internet, providing the video rental chain with another avenue for reaching consumers who want to rent and buy movies without traveling to a store.

abstract: A site points inquiring people to a powerful Internet tool.

headline: David G. Taylor, Engineer of a Bank’s Bailout, Dies at 79
abstract: David G. Taylor, who for six months in 1984 led one of the nation’s largest banks with a steady hand as it faced collapse and who helped negotiate what was then the biggest federal bailout of a financial institution, died Feb. 23 at his home in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 79.

headline: Baked-In Losses Weigh on G.E.
abstract: When Jack Welch kicked off his tenure at the helm of General Electric in 1981, the management guru Peter Drucker gave him a strategic pep talk. In what is now business school lore, Mr. Drucker suggested Mr. Welch ask himself a basic question: “If you weren’t already in a business, would you enter it today?”

abstract: If Johnson & Johnson — or anyone else, for that matter — is thinking about making a play for Schering-Plough, here’s a number worth considering: $1.25 billion.

abstract: Responding to pressure from federal bank regulators, Citigroup on Wednesday named Richard D. Parsons, the former chairman of Time Warner, to be its next chairman.

headline: Madoff Said to Have Gotten Millions Days Before Arrest
abstract: Days before his arrest, Bernard L. Madoff received $250 million from one of his oldest friends and the man who gave him his start on Wall Street.

abstract: The American International Group, which is reportedly negotiating for tens of billions of dollars in additional assistance amid mounting losses, has received offers from MetLife and Axa  for its American Life Insurance unit, Bloomberg News reported, citing three people familiar with the situation.

abstract: CBS’s crime shows on Tuesday came close to beating Fox’s line-up of “American Idol” and “Fringe” in the ratings, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: Wall Street Names on Black Enterprise’s Power List

The departures of two prominent African-American chief executives rekindled a debate about what barriers still exist for black executives seeking a corner office.

headline: Pfizer’s Talks to Buy Wyeth Move Forward
abstract: Pfizer‘s talks to acquire Wyeth, the drug company that makes the antidepressant Effexor, have advanced, bringing the two pharmaceuticals giants closer to a potential merger, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Friday.

abstract: With the healthcare mega-merger party in full swing, others may show up to take part in the festivities.

headline: Greenspan Said to Support Some Bank Nationalizations
abstract: Alan Greenspan, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve, told The Financial Times on Tuesday that short-term nationalization of some United States banks might be the “least bad solution” for the nation’s banking crisis.

headline: Baghdad’s Bodybuilder
abstract: His strong point is his general body proportions, with impressive “V” – taper trunk and wide shoulders.

abstract: It’s time for the politicians in Washington to see if they can find the answers to how the disgraced money manager Bernard L. Madoff was able to hide his purported $50 billion Ponzi scheme from the nation’s financial regulators for three decades.

headline: Daimler to Sell Stake to Abu Dhabi

headline: Middelhoff Teams With Former Bear Banker to Launch Firm
abstract: Former Bertelsmann chief Thomas Middelhoff has teamed up with former Bear Stearns banker Florian Lahnstein to launch a boutique investment firm, Berger Lahnstein Middelhoff & Partners.

headline: Social News Site Digg Cuts 10 Percent of Staff
abstract: Like other Web start-ups, Digg is trying to survive the economic meltdown by making a dash for profitability.

headline: Markets End Down Week on an Uptick
abstract: Wall Street ended a week of battering sell-offs on an mildly positive note as stock markets closed mostly higher despite a report showing that unemployment had surged to its highest level in 25 years, The New York Times’s Jack Healy writes.

headline: Yikes! Vizio Is No. 2
abstract: Vizio became the second-most popular TV brand in the fourth quarter of 2008 for one main reason: price.

headline: UBS Shares Get a Boost from Settlement
abstract: Confession it seems is good for the share price. At least that seemed to be the case for UBS, whose stock rose 3 percent on Thursday after the Swiss bank agreed to divulge the names of well-heeled Americans whom the authorities suspect of using offshore accounts at the bank to evade taxes.

headline: Spam. Spam. Spam. Spam.
abstract: Cellular spam can be its own sign of progress in Iraq.

headline: A Tool to Use On Car Repairmen
abstract: App of the week can tell you what you should pay for car repairs.

abstract: “Bonus” is not a four-letter word. But you wouldn’t know it from the noise emanating from Washington, Zurich and other capitals, says Breakingviews.

abstract: Some of the $350 million allocation will also fund local groups that will find ways to educate and encourage people to get broadband service.

abstract: It is called a reverse merger. And for a failing public biotechnology company, it can represent one last roll of the dice, The New York Times’s Andrew Pollack writes.

abstract: Fujifilm’s new FinePix S1500fd offers DSLR features at point-and-shoot prices.

abstract: The French automaker PSA Peugeot Citroën fired its chief executive Sunday and replaced him with a veteran of the steel industry.

abstract: The federal government is one step away from postponing the transition to digital television.

abstract: Verizon Wireless said Friday that it had completed its $5.9 billion purchase of Alltel, making Verizon the nation’s largest mobile phone company.

abstract: Credit Suisse’s top banker in Asia excluding Japan, Paul Raphael, is leaving the firm, according to an internal memo obtained by Dealbook.

abstract: Auto parts suppliers are in discussions with the Treasury Department about ways to address their financial troubles, industry trade groups said Wednesday.

headline: Chrysler’s New Ally Takes a Pragmatic Approach

abstract: Two of France’s largest banks said Monday they plan to merge their asset management businesses in a deal to create Europe’s fourth largest retail and institutional money manager.

abstract: Do hedge funds have human rights? In Europe, they just might.

abstract: The global economic upheaval has been giving a serious stress-test to the euro zone — and no one at Davos this week knows that better that Joaquin Almunia, the commissioner for economic and monetary affairs at the European Commission.

headline: V.C.s Clamp Down on Start-Ups
abstract: The last three months of 2008 may be remembered as the quarter when U.S. venture-capital investing fell off a cliff, raising fears the worsening recession will dampen an entrepreneurial sector that’s historically helped to regenerate New England business, The Boston Globe’s Robert Weisman reported.

headline: Exxon Mobil Sets Sights on Expansion
abstract: Exxon Mobil put on a show of strength on Thursday, pledging to increase investments in coming years, chiding rivals for mistimed acquisitions and reminding everyone it had the financial strength to make headway even as other companies pulled back, The New York Times’s Jad Mouawad reported.

headline: Talking Pictures – Iraq 2003-2008
abstract: In late October, three highly-experienced photographers who have covered every phase of the Iraq conflict, came together in the Baghdad Bureau of The New York Times to discuss the conflict and how it has evolved since 2003.

abstract: Citigroup may sell both its Japanese investment bank and brokerage, according to media reports, as the faltering U.S. lender looks to raise cash from a sale of global assets.

abstract: Thornburg Mortgage, a large and troubled provider of “jumbo” mortgage loans, said Tuesday that it might file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

abstract: Magna Entertainment, the Canadian racetrack and gambling company, will see its shares delisted from the Toronto Stock Exchange as of April 1, the company and the exchange said Tuesday.

abstract: A test version of Microsoft’s next operating system goes public on Friday.

abstract: Perella Weinberg Partners, the investment bank founded by Joseph R. Perella, the former vice chairman of Morgan Stanley, has been hired by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to advise it on strategies and transactions to stabilize the banking system.

abstract: Beijing is confident a Chinese bid to invest in Anglo-Australian miner Rio Tinto Group will not be hurt by its rejection of Coca-Cola‘s attempt to buy a Chinese juice maker, The Associated Press said, citing comments by a Cabinet official.

abstract: For administrators of hedge funds, the old rule that if you want a job done properly, you do it yourself, seems to no longer apply, Breakingviews says.

headline: In Germany, Executive Pay May Be Curbed
abstract: German Chancellor Angela Merkel has proposed curbs on executive pay for companies expecting to tap a 115 billion euro ($145 billion) German liquidity fund.

headline: Pfizer Bid for Wyeth Bodes Well for Roche Deal
abstract: Pfizer‘s mammoth bid for Wyeth is already reverberating through the pharmaceutical world.

headline: Wells Fargo Chairman Assails Tighter TARP Rules
abstract: Wells Fargo‘s chairman, Richard M. Kovacevich, didn’t want to take the federal government’s bailout money in the first place. Now, he is assailing the government for imposing new restrictions on financial institutions that receive federal money, and he calls a federal plan to subject big banks to stress tests “asinine.”

headline: Failed Banks Pose Test for Regulators
abstract: When regulators took over the First National Bank of Nevada last year, they faced a showdown with the Terrible Herbst, the mustachioed cowboy who boasts of being the “best bad man in the West.”

headline: Mattel Channels Obi-Wan: “Stretch Out With Your Feelings”
abstract: A new toy called Mindflex challenges players to elevate and maneuver a small ball using only the power of the mind.

headline: Don’t Count Out Cable Online
abstract: Cable companies are developing services so people can watch pay TV on the Internet, which may open up networks that haven’t been online.

headline: GE Finance Chief Calls Market Fears ‘Overdone’
abstract: Facing a precipitous slide in its share price, General Electric is mounting a defense of its financial strength in hopes of reassuring jittery stock and bond investors.

headline: The Tragedy of the Fishes
abstract: How fisheries have been depleted because of a lack of ownership rights.

headline: Googlers Rooting for Google Stock to Drop
abstract: From Miguel Helft at Bits:

headline: Maryland Bank Warned It Must Find a Buyer
abstract: The federal Office of Thrift Supervision has directed a Maryland bank to find a buyer by Friday or it will be subject to a possible takeover by a government conservator or receiver, The Associated Press reports.

headline: The Happiest States of America
abstract: State- and district-level results from the Gallup-Healthways Well-Being Index.

headline: Hummer’s Fate Said to Be Decided by Tuesday
abstract: By Tuesday, General Motors will have to decide whether its struggling Hummer brand will die a quiet death or live on with a new owner, The Associated Press reported.

headline: More Names of Note Appear on Madoff List
abstract: There was a time — was it only two months ago? — when people would have been proud to be on a list of Bernard L. Madoff’s customers. They had made the cut, and their money was getting the Madoff touch, growing steadily and solidly in good times and bad.

headline: Apture Raises $4.1 Million
abstract: Apture, which provides multimedia services to Web publishers and bloggers, said Tuesday that it has landed $4.1 million in a first round of financing, led by Clearstone Venture Partners.

headline: The Big Imbalance in the Room
abstract: Panelists from the United States, Europe and Asia tried to identify solutions to the No. 1 global imbalance being discussed here in Davos: excessive consumption in the United States, and excessive savings in China.

headline: Crédit Suisse Posts a Record Loss
abstract: Credit Suisse posted a worse-than-expected fourth-quarter net loss of 6 billion Swiss francs ($5.2 billion), taking it to its biggest-ever annual loss, due to poor trading and restructuring charges.

headline: Lawmakers Vent Ire as A.I.G. Hearing Begins
abstract: From the start, lawmakers at Wednesday’s hearing on the American International Group were lobbing criticism left and right — and that was well before the event’s star witness, A.I.G. chief executive Edward Liddy, got his turn in the spotlight.

headline: H.-P. Begins $2.7 Billion Note Sale, Report Says
abstract: Hewlett-Packard on Monday began a $2.7 billion, three-part sale of notes via Banc of America Securities, Deutsche Bank and RBS Greenwich Capital, according to IFR.

headline: Financial Stocks Push Markets Higher
abstract: Wall Street bounded back on Wednesday as investors hunted for bargains among battered financial stocks and cheered the prospect that Timothy F. Geithner would be confirmed as President Obama’s Treasury secretary.

headline: New iTunes Allows D.R.M.-Free Upgrades
abstract: Apple iTunes users can upgrade to copy music without limits.

headline: Madoff Must Stay in Jail Pending Sentencing
abstract: Bernard L. Madoff must remain in jail while he awaits sentencing after admitting running a nearly $65 billion investment fraud, a federal appeals court ruled on Friday.

headline: Q & A: Weighing a Heavy Laptop Repair
abstract: What to do and where to go if your laptop’s monitor cracks up.

headline: Charter in Talks to Give Stakes to Debt Holders
abstract: Apollo Management and several other investment firms are in talks to convert their debt holdings in Charter Communications, the troubled cable company, into equity stakes, The New York Times’s Michael J. de la Merced reported, citing people briefed on the negotiations.

headline: Microsoft Chief Still Stuck on Yahoo
abstract: Yahoo may have a new chief, but Steven A. Ballmer appears to be getting the same cold shoulder.

headline: Businesses: London Is Calling (With Free Rent)
abstract: London’s mayor, Boris Johnson, on Wednesday offered overseas companies willing to move to the capital a year of rent-free office space in an attempt to salvage the city’s reputation as a business center.

headline: Australia Extends Short-Selling Ban
abstract: Australia on Thursday extended its ban on short-selling of financial shares through May because of continued volatility in world markets.

headline: Britain’s P.E. Industry Gets Bad Grade on Transparency
abstract: Britain’s private equity industry may find itself back in the crosshairs of British regulators following a report that said that many of the buyout shops that had agreed to a voluntary industry code on transparency are not complying with it.

headline: Scenes of Madoff in Happier Times
abstract: More tidbits about alleged fraudster Bernard L. Madoff are emerging every day. The latest involves a new video of Mr. Madoff and his wife, Ruth, lounging on their yacht, visiting a winery and relaxing in an upscale hotel in Saint-Tropez in southern France.

headline: EBay Founder Tweets About an Unusual Lawsuit
abstract: From Brad Stone at Bits:

headline: Did Bank of America Mislead Investors?
abstract: Bank of America‘s not-so-surprising announcement on Friday that it is being bailed out by the federal government because of excessive losses at its new Merrill Lynch subsidiary raises a number of questions. The most significant one is this: What did Bank of America know and when did it know it? And why are Bank of America shareholders learning about the huge losses only now, after their shareholder vote on the Merrill deal?

headline: Open Wide. Now Wider…
abstract: Philips develops new super-wide TV designed to display wide-screen movies.

headline: Candover Mulls Split as Rivals Circle, Report Says
abstract: Candover is considering splitting itself into two, and is preparing to start talks with potential bidders about selling all or part of its listed vehicle, The Financial Times reported.

headline: HSBC May Need $30 Billion, Analysts Say
abstract: HSBC Holdings, Europe’s biggest bank, may have to raise as much as $30 billion in capital and halve its dividend as earnings are likely to deteriorate more than expected, Morgan Stanley analysts said on Tuesday.

headline: The Case for a G.M. Bankruptcy Filing
abstract: Amid a fierce national debate about how to fix General Motors, Rick Newman of U.S. News & World Report sees a lot of merit to the Chapter 11 approach.

headline: Goldman Loses, but Hold the Pity
abstract: In a business like investment banking, losing people is usually bad news.

headline: Audience Attracts Funding
abstract: Audience, a maker of mobile-phone technology intended to drown out background noise, has nabbed $15 million in a fourth round of funding.

headline: Cuomo Has More Questions for Thain on Merrill Bonuses
abstract: John A. Thain, the former chief of Merrill Lynch, faced six hours of questioning last week with the attorney general of New York.

headline: Another View: Imagining an A.I.G. Bankruptcy
abstract: If A.I.G. were to seek bankruptcy protection, David E. Wood of Anderson Kill Wood & Bender suggests that the conventional wisdom — that its insurance units’ assets are beyond the direct reach of creditors — could be challenged.

headline: Ratings: The Academy Awards Gain Ground
abstract: ABC’s live broadcast Sunday of the 81st Annual Academy Awards was up appreciably in the ratings over last year’s telecast, the least watched Oscars on record.

headline: Ex-Madam Says Some Wall St. Clients Billed Their Firms
abstract: Wall Street executives have been catching heat lately for picking up fancy furniture, flying private jets and enjoying other perks on the corporate dime. Now, the former operator of a high-priced prostitution ring in New York is alleging that clients who worked for some of Street’s best-known firms often used corporate credit cards to pay for sex.

headline: Side Deal with J&J Clouds Schering Sale
abstract: Merck‘s $41 billion acquisition of Schering-Plough was already generating controversy Monday morning, as analysts expressed concern that a side deal with Johnson & Johnson could bring complications.

headline: Harrah’s Getting Ready to Cut Debt, Report Says
abstract: Private-equity owned Harrah’s Entertainment is preparing a plan to reduce its $23 billion debt load, The Wall Street Journal reports, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: G.M.’s Bondholders Press for Better Terms
abstract: As General Motors seeks to retool itself to qualify for more government aid, the company has cited progress in talks with its bondholders. But how much progress has been made? That isn’t clear yet.

headline: F.T.C. Clears Dow’s Deal for Rohm and Haas
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission on Friday approved Dow Chemical’s $15.3 billion takeover of the rival chemical company Rohm and Haas — removing the last condition to closing the much-watched deal.

headline: On Plane Crashes and Other Crashes
abstract: In a workshop on Global Imbalances, Ricardo Hausmann of Harvard’s Center for International Development explained why air safety was so much better than financial market safety.

headline: Taking Stock of U.S. Bailout, Asian Stocks Are Down
abstract: Skepticism over the Obama administration’s latest plan to bail out the beleaguered banking industry dragged stock markets down in Asia, though not as steeply as the declines in the United States and Europe, The New York Times’s Bettina Wassener reported.

headline: Telecom Mogul Seeks Deal in Times Company
abstract: Carlos Slim Helú, the Mexican billionaire, is near a deal to invest about $250 million in The New York Times Company, helping to shore up the publishing company’s struggling finances, people briefed on the transaction told The Times.

headline: Expect a Room of Sullen Faces
abstract: Shareholder frustration is likely to make this proxy season one of the most contentious in years, as directors get the blame for shrinking nest eggs and plunging fund values.

headline: Federal Government to Lure Wall Street’s Jobless
abstract: All is not lost for Wall Streeters deprived of their megasalaries and lavish lifestyles after the financial tsunami that has wiped out so many jobs.

headline: HBO Signs Joe Buck
abstract: Sports announcer Joe Buck will host a new HBO program starting in May.

headline: Barclays Confirms Talks on Potential iShares Sale
abstract: British bank Barclays confirmed it had discussed selling its iShares unit, sending its stock sharply higher on Monday on hopes it will be able to avoid issuing new shares to bolster its capital, Reuters said.

headline: A Digital Copy of Inauguration Day
abstract: ABC, CBS, CNN and NBC are all selling DVDs of the day’s festivities through online stores.

headline: MGM Mirage Chief May Sell More Assets
abstract: MGM Mirage’s new chief executive officer, James Murren, will consider further casino sales, as part of his plan to reduce the company’s debt and overhaul its balance sheet.

abstract: A few charts plucked from the annual Economic Report of the President.

abstract: PART THREE: THE TEAMS

abstract: Panasonic’s new digital cameras offer ultra-wide-angle lenses.

Litinsky, chalked up gains of 17.1 percent to 18 percent net of fees last year despite the global stock market meltdown, according to a letter the firm sent to clients on Tuesday.

abstract: New XDSC memory cards will offer 2 terabytes of storage.

abstract: Of the $170 billion in government funds used to prop up American International Group, a large chunk has gone to buy soured securities — at full price — from big banks like Goldman Sachs.

headline: After Madoff, Regulatory Oversight of Auditors Is Back
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has quietly backed away from a rule that had allowed the accounting firm that audited Bernard L. Madoff Investment Securities to avoid oversight by a regulator that was created after the Enron and WorldCom scandals, The New York Times’s Floyd Norris reported.

headline: Solvency of Big Banks Is Questioned
abstract: Some of the nation’s large banks, according to economists and other finance experts, are like dead men walking, The New York Times’s Steve Lohr reports.

headline: Dr.  Doom Finds Promise in Obama’s Toxic-Asset Plan
abstract: Nouriel Roubini, a/k/a “Dr. Doom,” is giving the Obama administration’s new plan to buy toxic assets the thumbs up.

headline: From DealBook: Circuit City to Liquidate
abstract: The nation’s number-two tech retailer is seeking court approval to shut down, says our blog-cousin DealBook.

headline: Yes, Stewart, CNBC Still Trusts Cramer
abstract: Jim Cramer’s personal brand — not to mention that of CNBC, his employer — has taken a beating in the last month. But CNBC still trusts him.

headline: S.E.C. Reaches Back to Name General Counsel
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission appointed a new chief legal officer on Friday who knows his way around the agency’s offices.

headline: Band of America Said to Pursue Sale of Merrill Unit
abstract: Bank of America is considering a sale of First Republic Bank, a private entity it inherited from Merrill Lynch, news reports said, citing unnamed sources.

headline: Top 25 Lawyers Behind the Deals of the Year
abstract: American Lawyer named its top 25 deal makers of the year and most of them were involved in the various government-led bailouts and shotgun mergers that defined the 2008 dealscape. H. Rodgin Cohen, chairman of Sullivan & Cromwell, was ranked No. 1.

headline: Sanofi Gearing Up for Acquisitions, Reports Say
abstract: Taking its cue from Pfizer‘s $68 billion deal for Wyeth, Sanofi-Aventis, the French pharmaceuticals company, is reportedly getting ready to do some dealmaking of its own.

headline: Cuomo May Seek Return of Early Merrill Bonuses, Report Says
abstract: New York Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo may demand the return of $4 billion in bonuses paid by Merrill Lynch just before it was acquired by Bank of America, Bloomberg News reported, citing a person familiar with the matter.

headline: A.I.G. Moves Ahead With Asset Disposals, Report Says
abstract: American International Group, moving ahead with asset sales, has received the first round of bids for its aircraft leasing unit, and is expected to start shopping its asset management business soon, Reuters reported, citing people familiar with the matter said on Monday.

headline: Greed and Heritage
abstract: Bankers Trust fooled its customers, and had to sell out to Deutsche Bank. Is the cycle repeating.

headline: For Friends of Madoff, the Pain Was Personal
abstract: From Aspen to Palm Beach to New York, Bernard L. Madoff’s investment fraud left a trail of victims reeling from their financial losses and, often, a deep sense of personal betrayal.

headline: G20 A ‘Make or Break’ Event For Markets, Soros Says
abstract: The Group of 20 nations meeting next week is a “make or break event” for the global markets, investor George Soros said on Wednesday.

headline: Magazines Aimed at Bankers Suspend Operations
abstract: Doubledown Media, which chronicled the lavish life of bankers in magazines like Trader Monthly and Dealmaker, has suspended operations.

headline: Morgan, Citi to Pull Client Money From Swiss Fund
abstract: Morgan Stanley and Citigroup plan to pull out clients’ money from a nearly $8 billion fund run by the Swiss banking giant Union Bancaire Privée, after learning that it was exposed to Bernard L. Madoff’s operations, people briefed on the matter said.

headline: It’s the Economy, Girlfriend
abstract: The economic crisis came home to 27-year-old Megan Petrus early last year when her boyfriend of eight months, a derivatives trader for a major bank, proved to be more concerned about helping a laid-off colleague than comforting Ms. Petrus after her father had a heart attack.

headline: Ratings: ‘Anatomy’ Leads The Night
abstract: NBC ranked fourth among the broadcast networks on Thursday while ABC edged past CBS’s live college basketball coverage to lead the night overall.

headline: After a Dreary 2008, Venture Capitalists Are Cautious
abstract: Public offerings and acquisitions of venture-backed companies were down sharply in 2008, prompting a slowdown in new start-up investments in 2009.

headline: Lawmaker Offers Plan to Detect Future Madoffs
abstract: Could the nation’s accounting regulators have caught on to the $50 billion Ponzi scheme that Bernard L. Madoff is accused of running?

headline: Layoffs Herald a Heyday for Employee Lawsuits
abstract: More workers are being let go as corporate layoffs that began in earnest last year have accelerated in recent weeks. And more often, people are looking around and complaining that they have been unfairly or improperly dismissed.

headline: Goldman Chief Opposed to Full Bank Nationalization
abstract: Goldman Sachs‘ chief executive said he opposed the full nationalization of banks, but thought government stakes could be sensible in extreme situations, in an interview with German weekly Welt am Sonntag.

headline: Do We Have to Pay the A.I.G. Bonuses?
abstract: While footing the bill for American International Group‘s decision to pay $165 million in employee bonuses is an affront taxpayers, it may be a necessary evil, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook colmun.

headline: $25 Billion for Electric Cars Is Untouched
abstract: The future of the American auto industry is getting off to a slow start. The Energy Department has $25 billion to make loans to hasten the arrival of the next generation of automotive technology — electric-powered cars. But no money has been allocated so far, The New York Times’s Leslie Wayne reports.

headline: Hilco, Gordon Brothers Submit Bid for Fortunoff
abstract: Hilco and Gordon Brothers, two of the largest liquidation firms, have submitted a bid to handle the winding down of Fortunoff, the bankrupt luxury goods store.

headline: Rock Me AKG!
abstract: Serious headphones from the land of Falco and Amadeus.

headline: G.M. Bondholders Push Alternate Plan for Carmaker
abstract: Advisers to bondholders of General Motors said on Monday they have presented a framework plan to President Obama’s autos task force and the ailing automaker that provides the company’s best chance for an out-of-court restructuring, Reuters reported.

headline: Q & A: Flash? Not So Fast
abstract: How to make your flash drive even flashier.

headline: Venture Capitalist Pleads Guilty to Securities Fraud
abstract: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

headline: At Sovereign Funds, a History of Bad Timing
abstract: After becoming international wheelers and dealers just a few years ago, sovereign wealth funds have staged a retreat. Instead of hunting for bargains beyond their borders, many of these government-run investment pools seem to be staying close to home.

headline: World Leaders Wary of U.S. Economic Measures
abstract: Instead of receiving a warm embrace, American policies were rebuked again and again in rhetoric that recalled the anger of the Bush years — mainly aimed at what the world views as the new threat of protectionism by the United States.

headline: Tip of the Week: Correcting Images in Picasa
abstract: Picasa 3 has a one-touch fix for color and contrast issues with your pictures.

headline: Live From Davos 2009: Day 2
abstract: The captains of capitalism got an earful on the first day of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, where panelists and attendees took the world’s financiers to task for, among other things, hobbling the world economy and collecting bonuses for the privilege. It was a remarkable tone that reflected the feeling of gloom hanging over this year’s gathering of politicians, corporate bosses and other dignitaries.

headline: Bottling the Magic Behind Google and Facebook
abstract: A start-up called Cloudera, backed by some of Silicon Valley’s big names, hopes to sell services around the open-source software that powers big Web sites like Google, Yahoo and Facebook.

headline: New Leaders Hold Detroit’s Prospects in Their Hands
abstract: Frederick A. Henderson, a Detroit native known as Fritz, is the quintessential General Motors man. The son of a Buick sales manager, he has spent most of his adult life at G.M., often parachuting into troubled G.M. operations around the globe.

headline: New Investors Board Air Berlin
abstract: TUI Travel, Europe’s biggest travel company, said Monday that it is paying 28.5 million euros ($37.6 million) for a 19.9 percent stake in a German airline, Air Berlin.

headline: NATO’s Future? Davos Men and Women Wonder
abstract: In the post-Bush post-bubble era, it’s almost as hard to find a military hawk as it is to find a free-market capitalist.

headline: Missing Texas Financier Found in Virginia
abstract: The Federal Bureau of Investigation found the Texas financier Robert Allen Stanford in Virginia on Thursday and served him with civil legal papers from the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Wireless Electricity, Not So Far Off
abstract: Wireless power has been the Holy Grail. It may be closer than you think.

headline: GroSolar Snaps Up Borrego Unit
abstract: GroSolar, a New England solar installer, said Wednesday that it was buying the residential-installation business of Borrego Solar Systems, making the combined company the fourth-largest residential solar installer in the United States.

headline: Obama’s Speech: 52 Million-Plus TV Viewers
abstract: More than 52 million people watched President Obama’s first address to a joint session of Congress in prime time on Tuesday.

headline: Nationalize the Banks? Analyst Urges Other Options
abstract: Mike Mayo, the banking analyst at Deutsche Bank, thinks nationalizing the American banking system is a bad idea and believes the new Obama administration should be more proactive in finding long-term solutions to the nation’s banking problems.

headline: Trump and Lenders Temporarily Suspend Litigation, Report Says
abstract: The real estate developer Donald Trump and his lenders agreed to temporarily suspend litigation on the Trump International Hotel and Tower project in Chicago, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Successor Named for Merrill’s Brokerage Chief
abstract: Bank of America has named Dan Sontag to head Merrill Lynch Global Wealth Management, its retail brokerage unit, according to an internal memo.

headline: Geithner Grilled Over Tax Issue
abstract: President Obama convened his economic team on his first day in the White House amid renewed fears for the financial system’s fragility and fresh criticism in Congress of his two-year recovery plan. Yet the seat remained empty for the man he has designated “the chief economic spokesman for my administration.”

headline: The Sinister Theory of 9/11 on ‘Rescue Me’
abstract: In an episode of “Rescue Me,” a character claims that the Sept. 11 attacks were an “inside job” by the government. The actor who espouses the theories on camera, it turns out, also subscribes to them in real life.

headline: Merck to Buy Schering-Plough for $41.1 Billion
abstract: Merck, the American pharmaceutical giant, will pay $41 billion to acquire its rival Schering-Plough, the two companies said Monday.

headline: Reluctant Star in Limelight in Madoff Scandal
abstract: Harry Markopolos has emerged, quite reluctantly, as a star in the Bernard L. Madoff investment debacle, and book publishers and movie producers now want to tell his story, with him as the hero.

headline: Citi Said to Consider Joint Ventures for Units
abstract: Citigroup is hoping to create joint ventures with third parties as a way of shedding businesses it does not want, The New York Post reported, citing high-level Citi insiders.

headline: Citi’s Private Bank Chief Moves to Barclays
abstract: A longtime Citigroup executive, John Longley, has left the bank to take a position with Barclays Global Investors.

headline: Lazard Names Global M&A Head
abstract: Lazard said Monday that it has appointed Antonio Weiss, an investment banker based in Paris, as its newly created global head of mergers and acquisitions.

headline: China Says Coca-Cola Could Have Abused Juice Deal
abstract: China rejected Coca-Cola‘s bid to buy top local juice maker Huiyuan because it feared the U.S. multinational could abuse its position across the whole soft drinks market, an official said in remarks published on Wednesday, according to Reuters.

headline: Henry Kravis Did Not Buy This Chair
abstract: The auction world was left slack-jawed last month when a leather chair from the estate of the late Yves Saint Laurent was sold for nearly 22 million euros — or about $28 million.

headline: The Youngest Obama Flips for Video
abstract: Sasha Obama uses the Flip Mino videocamera for pre-inauguration events.

headline: Freedom Bank of Georgia Is Seized, the 17th This Year
abstract: Regulators shut down Freedom Bank of Georgia, making it the 17th failure this year of a federally insured bank.

headline: Record High Mass Layoffs
abstract: Employers laid off a record 508,859 workers in the fourth quarter in what the Labor Department calls extended mass layoff events — layoffs involving 50 or more workers for at least 31 days.

headline: Why I’m Now A Believer in Mail Goggles
abstract: I used to think Gmail’s Mail Goggles feature was cute, if a bit whimsical. That is, until…

headline: Q & A: Putting Photos on the Map
abstract: Fast and easy ways you can geotag your photos (i.e. attach location data to your snapshots).

headline: The Secret to Start-Up Success: Save Customers Money
abstract: Venture capitalists say that whether a start-up is in computers, green tech or health care, it needs to save customers money to succeed.

headline: Ratings: About 25 Million for ‘Idol’
abstract: A two-hour edition of Fox’s “American Idol,” in which the judges whittled the slate of contestants down to 36 semifinalists, dominated Wednesday night’s prime time ratings.

headline: Buying IndyMac at a Bargain Price
abstract: The private equity firms buying IndyMac, the failed California-based bank, will get loans and securities with a face value of $23 billion, and a couple of mortgage businesses for an outlay of just $1.6 billion in cash. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation also handed them several other benefits.

abstract: States are facing critical shortfalls in tax revenue that are likely to persist after the stimulus money runs out.

abstract: Though Bernard L. Madoff has gone to jail, awaiting his sentencing, the number of claims that the court-appointed trustee for his firm must sort through has only grown quickly.

abstract: The nation’s number-two tech retailer is seeking court approval to shut down, says our blog-cousin DealBook.

abstract: The White House plan to rescue the nation’s financial system, announced on Tuesday by Timothy F. Geithner, the Treasury secretary, is far bigger than anyone predicted and envisions a far greater government role in markets and banks than at any time since the 1930s.

abstract: Sony has announced new Cyber-cameras that take even more guesswork out of snapping a shot.

abstract: Timothy Geithner, President Barack Obama’s pick for Treasury secretary, has two charges to answer during his confirmation hearing Wednesday before the Senate Finance Committee, relating to his tax history and his role in financial bailouts to date.

abstract: Panasonic adds a new Micro Four Thirds hybrid camera with high-definition video capabilities.

abstract: Former U.S. Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson called for an overhaul of financial regulation in an opinion piece in the Financial Times on Tuesday, largely reiterating a plan he proposed in March 2008.
