abstract: The war of words between NRG Energy and its would-be acquirer continues.

headline: Citi Chief Defends Bank’s Financial Strength
abstract: Citigroup chief executive Vikram Pandit sought to reassure Citi colleagues Monday that the bank’s capital ratios and earnings power are strong. DealBook has the internal memo.

headline: Trolling for Patents to Fight Patent Trolls
abstract: RPX hopes to profit by buying patents. But unlike other intellectual property firms, its plan is never to sue companies that infringe on the patents it buys.

headline: The Health Effects of Social Networking
abstract: Researchers are suggesting that social networking sites might be bad for physical and mental health, especially in children.

headline: Facebook Won’t Budge on Breastfeeding Photos
abstract: Some mothers are upset over Facebook’s policy of removing some photos showing women breastfeeding their children.

headline: Brawn GP Formula One Team
abstract: It will be interesting to see how long people in casual bar conversation continue to ask me the same question when we talk about Formula One and the economic crisis: “So, how many teams have dropped out of Formula One now?”

headline: Ticketmaster Said to Seek Merger With Big Promoter
abstract: Ticketmaster Entertainment, the ticket-selling giant, is in talks with Live Nation and the Anschutz Entertainment Group over a potential merger with either music promoter, The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced reported, citing people briefed on the talks.

headline: Asian Markets Gain
abstract: Asian stock markets rose strongly Monday, with benchmarks in Tokyo and Shanghai gaining more than 2 percent, as last week’s rally on Wall Street buoyed investor hopes for 2009.

headline: Madoff Trustee Mails Out 8,000 Claims Forms
abstract: The court-appointed trustee overseeing Bernard L. Madoff’s firm has sent out more than 8,000 claims forms to its customers as they seek to recover collectively billions of dollars from the money manager’s alleged Ponzi scheme.

headline: Ping An Plans Private Equity Fund, Report Says
abstract: Ping An Insurance, the second-largest insurer in China, plans to form a private equity arm this year, Reuters reported, citing two people with direct knowledge of the plan, as Beijing encourages private equity investment to bolster the economy.

headline: Ratings: Nearly 14 Million Watch ‘Survivor’ Premiere
abstract: The return of “Survivor” to CBS’s line-up on Thursday helped the network claim victory as the night’s most watched network, but a “Grey’s Anatomy” crossover episode with “Private Practice” gave ABC an edge in the demographic of adults 18 to 49.

headline: Canadian Mining Company Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: Redcorp Ventures, a Canadian gold-and-silver mining company, filed for bankruptcy in the United States and Canada, citing cost overruns and a lack of financing.

headline: JuicyCampus, an Online Collegiate Tabloid, Folds
abstract: From Jenna Wortham at Bits:

headline: Stimulus Plans Might ‘Do Good,’ but Not Actually Stimulate
abstract: When the government hires employees or makes purchases, the ultimate economic effect of these actions depends on what private sector activity is displaced, an economist writes.

headline: Citi Urges MySpace Users to Spend Wisely
abstract: Citigroup, a recipient of three taxpayer bailouts, is using a new credit card to teach MySpace users about fiscal responsibility.

headline: UBS Ousts Top Banker Who Served U.S. Clients
abstract: UBS, the Swiss bank under a growing federal investigation for tax fraud, has forced out the executive formerly in charge of secret offshore accounts for wealthy Americans, the bank said Sunday, according to The New York Times’s Lynnley Browning.

headline: Citi Plans Elaborate Office Consolidation
abstract: In a move bound to feed public furor over perks at bailed-out banks, Citigroup is planning to spend about $10 million on new offices for its chief executive and his lieutenants, a project that calls for premium millwork and at least on Sub-Zero refrigerator.

headline: The Ultimate Growth Industry
abstract: For a long-term investment in a socially responsible growth industry offering consistently high returns, an economist recommends public spending on early childhood education.

headline: ABC May Bring ‘Millionaire’ Back to Prime Time
abstract: ABC may present a primetime revival of the game show “Who Wants to Be a Millionaire” this summer.

headline: Economic Art
abstract: The work of German artist Andreas Nicolas Fischer, whose work is inspired by economic data.

headline: The 69-Cent iTune, Unrestricted
abstract: Apple makes it easier to copy iTunes, and restructures download pricing.

headline: Greystripe Raises Money to Peddle Ads in Cellphone Games
abstract: Greystripe, which raised $5.5 million in additional funding, says that Web ads work just as well on iPhones.

headline: AboutUs Banks $5 Million in Funding
abstract: AboutUs, the wiki that’s working to capture detailed information about every site on the Web, has secured $5 million in Series A funding. The round was led by Voyager Capital with a $2.5 million investment, ReadWriteWeb reported.

headline: Weekend Thoughts on Deals Big and Small
abstract: This last week has seen some blockbuster news in the form of Merrill Lynch/Bank of America, Steven P. Jobs/Apple and, of course, the inauguration of President Obama. In the wake of these stories, you might have missed some of the smaller occurrences of the week. So I thought I would bring you up to date. Nonetheless, I can’t resist starting with some brief thoughts on Bank of America and the continuing allegations of nondisclosure.

headline: Another View: The Government Is Madoff’s Biggest Winner
abstract: Andrew N. Lerman, a certified public accountant in White Plains, N.Y., argues that the biggest beneficiary of the Bernard L. Madoff scandal was the federal government through the taxes it collected. Mr. Lerman, who is working for several victims of the fraud, has spoken to several United States senators, including Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey and Charles Schumer, Democrat of New York.

headline: Merrill Reportedly Paid Bonuses Early as Merger Closed
abstract: The controversy over Bank of America‘s acquisition of Merrill Lynch appeared to grow on Thursday with a report in the Financial Times that Merrill paid out billions of dollars in bonuses to its employees three days before the sale went through — and well before it has paid out bonuses in previous years.

headline: Obama’s Housing Plan: Who Will Benefit?
abstract: The president says he wants to help people who played by the rules and not those who bought more home than they could afford. His plan will help both.

headline: Losses Mount Up
abstract: For the first time, the Standard & Poor’s 500 is on its way to a quarter in which the component companies will report overall losses rather than profits.

headline: LED’s Good Housekeeping Seal
abstract: LED lighting products are now eligible to receive the government’s Energy Star imprimatur.

headline: For Windows 7 Beta, Updates to Download
abstract: More updates for the next generation Windows OS.

headline: Of Twitter, Stocks and Public Offerings
abstract: Initial public offerings are an endangered species on Wall Street these days — especially for untested, and often unprofitable, venture-backed companies.

headline: A Push to Free Capital for Emerging Markets
abstract: With governments focused on shoring up domestic lending, the world’s major financial businesses are pushing to help the flow of financing to subsidiaries in emerging markets like Eastern Europe, The New York Times’s Matthew Saltmarsh writes.

headline: Witness on Madoff Tells of Fear for Safety
abstract: The man who tried unsuccessfully for almost a decade to spur federal securities regulators to investigate Bernard L. Madoff did not initially disclose his own identity to regulators because he feared for his life, reports Diana B. Henriques in The New York Times, according to testimony he has apparently prepared for a Congressional hearing Wednesday morning.

headline: In 2nd Inquiry, UBS Finds Itself in a Bind
abstract: The UBS memo was blunt: the “Swiss solution” could help affluent Americans.

headline: Netbooks: A Curse or a Blessing in an Imploding PC Market?
abstract: Sales of PC chips fell off a cliff in the fourth quarter, but they would have been worse without the boom in netbooks.

headline: Can Businesses Do Well and Do Good?
abstract: An economist discusses how ethical businesses should be, in light of their duties to their shareholders and to “the greater good.”

headline: Wachovia Acquisition Drags Down Wells Fargo
abstract: Wells Fargo‘s $2.55 billion fourth-quarter loss on Wednesday is the first sign that its hurried acquisition of the troubled Wachovia Corporation would be a long and difficult struggle.

headline: Foster’s Decides to Keep Wine Business After All
abstract: Foster’s Group, Australia’s biggest brewer, will retain its global wine business because the worldwide economic recession is making it difficult to find a buyer.

headline: New Sony TV Models: Worth the Wait?
abstract: Sony will introduce its new 2009 HDTV lineup this Monday, but a web site has already leaked prices and some features for its sets.

headline: Volcker Suggests Ways to Refine Bank Regulations
abstract: Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve chairman who is leading President Obama’s Economic Recovery Advisory Board, called Wednesday for fundamental changes in the regulation of financial instruments and institutions, especially of those firms whose collapse can put the financial system at risk, The New York Times’s Sharon Otterman reports.

headline: Valin Buys Stake in Fortescue for $798 Million
abstract: China’s Hunan Valin Iron and Steel Group is spending 1.24 billion Australian dollars ($798 million) to build a 16.5 percent stake in Australia’s Fortescue Metals.

headline: Executive Shake-Up at Ivy Asset Management
abstract: The Bank of New York Mellon Corporation’s hedge fund unit, Ivy Asset Management, has shaken up its executive ranks and retooled its compensation plan as it tries to navigate the broad changes sweeping the battered hedge fund industry.

headline: ING Reviews Its U.S. Options, Report Says
abstract: ING Group is gauging the implications of the U.S. bank rescue aid plan announced earlier this month for its activities there, the Dutch banking and insurance group’s next chief executive told a Dutch newspaper Saturday, Reuters said.

headline: Lower (and More Realistic) Presidential Expectations
abstract: Today a new presidency begins, carrying with it the hopes of millions throughout the world. President Obama is a remarkable person, but he would be better served with a narrower, and more reasonable, set of job expectations, an economist writes.

headline: Wine as an Economic Indicator
abstract: The relationship between alcohol sales and the economy.

headline: Fifth Third Sells Stake in Processing Unit to Buyout Shop
abstract: Fifth Third Bancorp said on Monday that it had signed a deal to sell a 51 percent stake in its payment processing unit to a private equity firm, Advent International, for $561 million.

headline: ABC Pursues Television Widgets
abstract: Fans of ABC’s “Lost” and “Good Morning America” – and perhaps executives at rival networks – may want to pay careful attention to an idea the Walt Disney Company plans to discuss at the Consumer Electronics Show on Thursday afternoon.

headline: Microsoft Live Search in Quest for New Name and Design
abstract: Microsoft is testing a new design for its search engine, which it plans to rename. Kumo.com is one possibility to replace the Windows Live Search brand.

headline: Icahn Says He Has No Plans to Shop Lions Gate
abstract: Carl C. Icahn, the activist investor, said he had no plans to push for a sale of Lions Gate Entertainment in the current environment, but he criticized the Hollywood studio’s expenses for being too high and called its purchase of TV Guide “reckless,” Reuters reported.

headline: Auto Parts Suppliers May Get Aid
abstract: The Obama administration signaled its intent Thursday to provide broad relief to the American auto industry with the creation of a $5 billion fund to aid troubled parts suppliers.

headline: Citadel Keeps Gates Up, but Sets Redemption Plan
abstract: Citadel Investment Group has decided to continue suspending redemptions from its two largest funds for another quarter after freezing them last year, but will institute a new program to allow withdrawals.

headline: HBO to Show Sunday’s Inaugural Event Live
abstract: HBO’s exclusive telecast of the opening celebration for Barack Obama’s inauguration will now be shown live.

headline: Global Sports Forum: Formula One Edition
abstract: PART THREE: THE TEAMS

headline: Panasonic Goes Wide With 25mm Lenses
abstract: Panasonic’s new digital cameras offer ultra-wide-angle lenses.

headline: JHL Capital Reports Gains of Up to 18%
abstract: John Paulson isn’t the only hedge fund manager to come out of 2008 with big profits. The Chicago-based JHL Capital Group, a small firm run by James H. Litinsky, chalked up gains of 17.1 percent to 18 percent net of fees last year despite the global stock market meltdown, according to a letter the firm sent to clients on Tuesday.

headline: Another View: Advice on Lawyers for Madoff Victims
abstract: Eric M. Rosenberg, an attorney and president of LitigationProofing, a firm that helps companies limit exposure to potential lawsuits, offers this view of what Bernard L. Madoff’s investors should consider when they are choosing lawyers to seek recovery of their money:

headline: New SDXC Memory Cards to Hit 2 Terabytes
abstract: New XDSC memory cards will offer 2 terabytes of storage.

headline: Adding Up A.I.G.’s Backdoor Bailouts
abstract: Of the $170 billion in government funds used to prop up American International Group, a large chunk has gone to buy soured securities — at full price — from big banks like Goldman Sachs.

headline: After Madoff, Regulatory Oversight of Auditors Is Back
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has quietly backed away from a rule that had allowed the accounting firm that audited Bernard L. Madoff Investment Securities to avoid oversight by a regulator that was created after the Enron and WorldCom scandals, The New York Times’s Floyd Norris reported.

headline: Solvency of Big Banks Is Questioned
abstract: Some of the nation’s large banks, according to economists and other finance experts, are like dead men walking, The New York Times’s Steve Lohr reports.

headline: Dr.  Doom Finds Promise in Obama’s Toxic-Asset Plan
abstract: Nouriel Roubini, a/k/a “Dr. Doom,” is giving the Obama administration’s new plan to buy toxic assets the thumbs up.

headline: From DealBook: Circuit City to Liquidate
abstract: The nation’s number-two tech retailer is seeking court approval to shut down, says our blog-cousin DealBook.

headline: Madoff Lawyer Presses Case for Bail
abstract: Bernard L. Madoff’s lawyer asked a three-judge panel on Thursday to restore his bail while he awaits sentencing in a $65 billion Ponzi scheme, but the prosecution asserted that the risk of flight dictated his continued detention.

headline: The 240-Gigabyte iPod Has a Debut, Sort Of
abstract: Rapid Repair will upgrade fifth-generation iPods to a new 240-gigabyte hard drive.

headline: Goldman Answers A.I.G. Questions and Raises New Ones
abstract: Goldman Sachs offered some more details about its positions with American International Group, but the explanations raised new questions as well.

headline: Rep. Bachus on Bailouts, Bonuses and Bankruptcy
abstract: In an interview with DealBook, Spencer Bachus, the ranking member of the House Financial Services Committee, expressed support for reforming Wall Street but criticized the secrecy of federal bailouts and efforts to set the terms of executive pay.

headline: SAS Warms to Open-Source One Letter at a Time
abstract: The world’s largest statistics company is ready to give the open-source and beloved R programming language a shot.

headline: Icahn Puts Another $250 Million Into His Fund
abstract: The billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn put another $250 million into his hedge fund at the beginning of the year after suffering further losses in the fourth quarter on investments in Motorola and Yahoo, according to a letter he sent to investors.

headline: Learning From G.E. as Spin Season Approaches
abstract: As companies prepare for a new season of investor updates, they would do well to consider a recent conference call by General Electric‘s Jeffrey Immelt, Jack Flack says.

headline: ‘Cost-Effectiveness Analysis’ and U.S. Health Care
abstract: An economist discusses two politically-sensitive health care ideas that were in play during drafts of the stimulus bill, and explains why only one of those proposals actually made it to the final version of the bill.

headline: Economists Sound Off at Davos
abstract: Reporting from the World Economic Forum in Davos, CNBC interviewed a number of prominent economists and business leaders about the global financial crisis and what can be done.

headline: Insana to Leave SAC Capital
abstract: Ron Insana, the former CNBC anchor, has decided to leave his post at SAC Capital just six months after he was hired as a managing director, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook.

headline: All Bernie, All the Time
abstract: From Floyd Norris at Notions on High and Low Finance:

headline: Satyam Names Chief and Secures Bank Loans
abstract: Satyam Computer Services, the computer outsourcing company, has appointed a chief executive and secured $130 million in bank loans in the wake of a $1 billion fraud scandal, the company’s board said Thursday.

headline: Halliburton to Pay $559 Million to Settle Bribery Probe
abstract: Halliburton will pay a $559 million fine to end an investigation of its former KBR unit if the U.S. government approves the settlement, the largest penalty against a U.S. company for charges of bribery under federal law.

headline: V.C.’s Speak Out Against Tax Proposal
abstract: Last week, President Barack Obama announced his intention to raise taxes on carried interest for hedge funds and private equity firms as part of his bold new budget plan.

headline: French Bankers Trade Bonuses for Bailout
abstract: France’s top bankers agreed Tuesday to give up their 2008 bonuses in exchange for a new round of government aid to bolster their companies’ balance sheets.

headline: The Return of the Dissenters
abstract: From Floyd Norris at Notions on High and Low Finance:

headline: Microsoft Video Looks 10 Years Ahead
abstract: OfficeLabs, a Microsoft skunkworks, has produced videos that suggest what future computing may be like.

headline: Walid Trumpets Billionaire Status Amid Turmoil
abstract: There are 30 percent fewer billionaires in the world now, according to Forbes. Prince Walid bin Talal, the Saudi royal who has taken a hit from his Citigroup investment, would like you to know he is still one of them.

headline: Goldman Denies Holding Urgent Meeting Over Geithner Plan
abstract: Goldman Sachs denied a CNBC television report on Thursday that it had convened an “emergency” meeting of top investors earlier this week, prompted by worries that Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner’s bank rescue plan was not viable.

headline: Goldman’s Hurdle to a Stock Sale: Buffett
abstract: Executives at Goldman Sachs made it clear that they wanted to give back the government aid the firm had received. But if the firm seeks to raise capital in the public markets afterward, it still needs to reckon with Warren Buffett, Breakingviews says.

headline: Intel Boss Says Sun Was Shopped All Over
abstract: Paul Otellini told Intel employees that Sun has been on a road show, offering itself to every potential suitor it could find.

headline: What’s Your Favorite Tech Folk Remedy?
abstract: We want your favorite unconventional fixes to common (or not-so-common) tech problems.

headline: Obama to Set Pay Cap; Super Return 2009
abstract: The Obama administration is expected to impose a cap of $500,000 for top executives at companies that receive large amounts of bailout money, The New York Times’ Edmund L. Andrews and Vikas Bajaj write, citing people familiar with the plan. Executives would also be prohibited from receiving any bonuses above their base pay, except for normal stock dividends.

headline: A Bear Market for Getting Hitched?
abstract: There could be fewer newlyweds celebrating their first Valentine’s Day this year at chic Manhattan restaurants favored by the Wall Street elite.

headline: The Drive for More Memory
abstract: Flash drives can make computing more portable.

headline: Evercore Hires Ex-Vice Chairman of UBS
abstract: div class=”thumbnail”>Small boutique investment banks are taking advantage of the carnage that has befallen their larger rivals to pick up top talent.

headline: Icahn Says Bankruptcy Laws Hobble Private Investment
abstract: Activist investor Carl C. Icahn called for changes in federal bankruptcy laws, which he argues are thwarting private investment in the banking system.

headline: Financial Regulatory Reform Is Coming
abstract: The game has begun.

headline: Canvas Takes $750,000 in First Round
abstract: Canvas, maker of software that allows the transfer of paper forms into digital applications, said it had landed $750,000 of its targeted $1 million first round, VentureBeat reported.

headline: Google Tweaks Search Functions
abstract: A pair of improvements help refine inquiries on Google.

headline: Reader Response: Women in the Labor Force Around the World
abstract: A reader asks: Do any of the world’s countries have a workforce that is majority-female?

headline: Calls for Clarity in New Bank Bailout
abstract: When Congress passed the $700 billion bank bailout last October, the Bush administration confronted a thorny question: Should it require banks to account for how they spend taxpayer money?

headline: Secondaries Are Bright Spot for L.S.E.
abstract: The London Stock Exchange said Thursday that while trading had fallen sharply since October, the scramble to raise new equity pushed secondary fund-raising levels to a record high.

headline: Madoff Lawyer Responds to $177 Billion Forfeiture Demand
abstract: A lawyer for Bernard L. Madoff on Tuesday argued with federal prosecutors’ demand that the financier forfeit about $177 billion in proceeds and property tied to his huge fraud.

headline: All That Twitters May Not Be Gold, Analysts Say
abstract: Twitter‘s popularity has fueled speculation that buyers might be interested in the microblogging service, but analysts at Sanford Bernstein argue that potential acquirers should think twice.

headline: As Banks Flounder, the Perks Play On
abstract: Despite the current problems of Bank of America and Wachovia and the passage of nearly a decade, the two men who built the Charlotte-based firms continue to collect a paycheck or perks from their former employers.

headline: Hot Trends at the CTIA Phone Conference
abstract: What’s going on at the big U.S. wireless convention this year.

headline: Men’s Designer Is Squeezed in Effort to Raise Cash
abstract: His $5,000 shrunken suits are the height of men’s fashion now. But Thom Browne, a highly touted designer whose wares are spotlighted in luxury stores like Bergdorf Goodman, is desperately trying to head off a cash crunch, The New York Post reported.

headline: Suncor Deal Protects a Canadian Identity in Oil Sands
abstract: When markets were rising, many Canadians fretted about leveraged buyouts that put several of the country’s largest corporations under foreign control. The markets’ collapse, however, created the environment for the creation of a new, large Canadian energy firm, The New York Times’s Ian Austen reported.

headline: Crime and Punishment: Some Costs of Inequality
abstract: Inequality can lead to inefficiency when it intensifies social conflict, an economist writes.

headline: Hartmarx, Obama’s Clothier, Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: A little less than a week after President Obama was sworn in, the maker of his suits has filed for bankruptcy.

headline: Could ‘Lipstick Jungle’ Find a Cable Home?
abstract: “Lipstick Jungle,” the NBC series that came close to cancellation last fall, may mount a comeback on another channel.

headline: Under the Big Top, Washington Style
abstract: A look at some of the more bizarre, insightful and hilarious comments uttered by members of Congress in the modern-day inquisition of Wall Street executives.

headline: New Indictment Against Dreier in Fraud Case
abstract: Prosecutors have unveiled a beefed-up indictment against Marc S. Dreier, the New York lawyer suspected of bilking hedge funds out of about $700 million, The Associated Press said.

headline: Future F1 champions
abstract: I find it difficult to remember a year in which there was no clear favorite new young talent on the way in to Formula One the way this year strikes me. I have a story in tomorrow’s IHT (and on the web now) about that, as part of a series we’re doing on the young rising talents in all sports.

headline: Weather Report: Mists Over Davos
abstract: The first official day of the World Economic Forum 2009 is expected to bring clouds and areas of freezing fog, or what a local report more poetically called “wafts of mist.”

headline: Middle-Aged and Worried
abstract: A recent survey from Gallup found that Americans age 40 to 49 were most likely to report worrying about money.

headline: A Plan for A.I.G.’s Current Payroll
abstract: It is time to start thinking about how to equitably pay the janitors mopping up the American International Group’s derivatives mess, Breakingviews says.

headline: Austria Appoints Overseer at Bank in Madoff Case
abstract: The management of Bank Medici, the small Austrian merchant bank that emerged as one of the largest victims of the Bernard L. Madoff scandal, resigned on Friday, making room for a government-appointed accountant to temporarily take over day-to-day operations, The New York Times’s Julia Werdigier reported.

headline: Certicom Receives New Takeover Bid from RIM
abstract: Certicom said it received a second takeover bid from Research In Motion, this one for for 3 Canadian dollars a share, in what could lead to a bidding war with rival VeriSign.

headline: Samsung Introduces Ultra-Wide Cameras
abstract: Samsung announces two new cameras with 24mm ultra-wide-angle zoom lenses.

headline: A Reborn Alitalia Flies into Troubled Skies
abstract: The airline’s name is unchanged. The flight attendants will not be sporting new uniforms. It is not even getting a new logo.

headline: Video: Carlyle Chief on Buyouts, Titans and ‘Bad Banks’
abstract: David Rubenstein, a co-founder of the Carlyle Group, says that the private equity industry shouldn’t be relegated to the sidelines just yet.

headline: The Ballot: Inside Iraq’s Voting Booth
abstract: What do you get when you take 14,300 candidates vying for 440 seats in a nascent democracy where suicide bombings are a daily threat? One answer is potential chaos.

headline: BofA Sells Bank Stake as Chief Forgoes Bonus
abstract: Bank of America, raising cash to weather a dismal market at home, sold a $2.83 billion chunk of its holding in China Construction Bank on Wednesday, dragging the Chinese bank’s stock 6 percent lower.

headline: Research Firm Reports Decline in Academy Award Ad Spending
abstract: Advertising spending during the Academy Awards fell by an estimated 10 percent this year, even though ABC sold two more minutes of commercials than it did in 2008.

headline: Cuomo Presses in Court for Merrill Bonus Information
abstract: The office of Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York on Wednesday filed yet another appeal in state court seeking the release of the names of Merrill Lynch’s top earners last year.

headline: CNBC’s Senior News Executive is Leaving
abstract: The senior news executive at CNBC said Tuesday that he would leave the job next month, in the midst of what is arguably the biggest story in the business channel’s history.

headline: No-Contract iPhones Don’t Add Up
abstract: In March AT&T will sell iPhones, no contract required. But it’s far from a good deal.

headline: Star Tribune Employees Put Some Blame on P.E. Debt
abstract: Some employees of The Star Tribune of Minneapolis, it seems, are not feeling so good about their private equity owners after the newspaper filed for bankruptcy on Thursday.

abstract: PART THREE: THE TEAMS

abstract: Panasonic’s new digital cameras offer ultra-wide-angle lenses.

abstract: New XDSC memory cards will offer 2 terabytes of storage.

abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has quietly backed away from a rule that had allowed the accounting firm that audited Bernard L. abstract: Some of the nation’s large banks, according to economists and other finance experts, are like dead men walking, The New York Times’s Steve Lohr reports.

headline: From DealBook: Circuit City to Liquidate
abstract: The nation’s number-two tech retailer is seeking court approval to shut down, says our blog-cousin DealBook.

headline: CBS Beams ‘Star Trek’ Episodes to iPhones
abstract: CBS has introduced an iPhone application for its TV.com site bringing full episodes of TV series over WiFi and cellular connections.

headline: ‘Beatlemania for Nerds’ at Live Digg Show
abstract: A live performance of Diggnation, the weekly online video, drew a large and enthusiastic crowd on Saturday night.

headline: Repair Rather Than Replace
abstract: Not buying anything new for a while? Your local repairmen thank you.

headline: Wiretap Affidavits Ordered Unsealed in Spitzer Case
abstract: From William K. Rashbaum at City Room:

headline: Amazon.com’s New Kindle Is Lighter, Brighter and Chattier
abstract: Amazon.com’s Kindle 2 electronic book reader, unveiled Monday, is thinner, offers text-to-speech ability and has a crisper display and longer battery life than the original.

headline: Ross Said to Be in Talks to Buy Bad R.B.S. Loans
abstract: The billionaire investor Wilbur Ross is leading a consortium that is in talks with the Royal Bank of Scotland and the British government about buying some of the British bank’s bad loans, The Times of London reported.

headline: Société Générale Reports 4th-Quarter Profit
abstract: Société Générale said Wednesday that it expected the market environment to remain challenging throughout 2009, after posting fourth-quarter profits that came in below market expectations.

headline: EBay’s Skype Comments Create Sale Buzz
abstract: Is eBay sending out smoke signals that Skype could be had for the right price?

headline: The Real Winners of the Bonus Cuts
abstract: It’s now clear that 2008 Wall Street bonuses have been cut at least in half. Outsiders remain aghast that bonuses have been paid at all. But that isn’t the only shocker. In this supposedly most meritocratic of industries, staff at the worst-performing institutions have absorbed the least pain, Breakingviews writes.

headline: Stop the Presses: Congress Is Angry!
abstract: This is the week the political system ran off the rails.

headline: A.I.G. Was Like Big Hedge Fund, Fed Chief Says
abstract: The American International Group has drawn scorn from legions of taxpayers and lots of lawmakers (not to mention the writers at “Saturday Night Live”). And Ben Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, is pretty peeved at the company as well.

headline: Spreading Pain in A.I.G.’s Bailout
abstract: The government needs to get tough with the insurer American International Group. Even at the time of the first bailout in September, the company seemed like a black hole, Breaking Views argues.

headline: SanDisk Mulls Equity Offering
abstract: SanDisk, which on Monday posted a larger-than-expected fourth-quarter loss, said it may seek to raise cash through a dilutive stock sale.

headline: For Peugeot Chief, History Repeats Itself
abstract: Christian Streiff lasted just over two years as chief executive of PSA Peugeot Citroën — far longer than the 100 days he spent at Airbus before clashes with the plane maker’s parent company, European Aeronautic, Defense & Space, got him cashiered there.

headline: Tesla Will Build Battery Packs for Other Electric Cars
abstract: Tesla’s electric sedan has been delayed, but it will build battery packs for Daimler’s electric Smart car.

headline: Another View: A Local Fix for a Global Mess
abstract: Many of the participants at the World Economic Forum will be thinking about big, global solutions to the current financial mess. But should they also be thinking small?

headline: Wells Fargo Takes 4th-Quarter Loss on Wachovia Deal
abstract: Wells Fargo reported a $2.55 billion loss for its fourth quarter on Wednesday, as the bank’s profits were weighed down by mortgage assets it assumed when it took over Wachovia weeks ago.

headline: Oh, for a Little Extra Cash
abstract: Access to liquidity is the top worry of global chief executive officers, according to a survey that PricewaterhouseCoopers has published at the beginning of each Davos meeting since 2003.

headline: After SAC, Insana Returns to TV
abstract: Three years ago, when money flowed easily, Ronald G. Insana left CNBC to hang his own shingle as a hedge fund manager. Now, as he returns to television, he has but one misgiving about his foray into moneymaking.

headline: Sirius and Echostar in Talks on Debt, Report Says
abstract: Sirius XM Satellite Radio has been in talks with EchoStar about its accumulation of Sirius’ debt for several weeks, but both firms have not reached a resolution, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: Apax Said to Sell Minority Stake
abstract: Apax Partners, the British private equity group, has sold 7.7 percent of its management company to Singaporean and Australian investors, according to The Financial Times. Apax plans to put the cash raised from the deal into a permanent fund that it will invest in future buyout funds, the report said.

headline: Baby Boomers, Luddites? Not So Fast
abstract: A new study from Forrester Research says that older Americans are readily adopting technologies like social networking, blogs and online video.

headline: Another Manufacturer Drops Plasma
abstract: Vizio stops selling plasma TVs, in favor of LCD technology.

headline: BlackRock’s Fink: Why the Treasury Plan Could Work
abstract: To Laurence D. Fink, the chairman and chief executive of BlackRock, the giant money manager, the new Treasury investment program is a highly attractive way to bring private money to help repair the financial system.

headline: Citi Holds Talks With U.S. Over Bigger Ownership Stake
abstract: From Eric Dash, a DealBook colleague:

headline: U.S. Toxic Asset Plan Not For Private Equity, Canning Says
abstract: Madison Dearborn‘s John Canning Jr. doesn’t think private equity firms are going to be the big players in the U.S. government’s plan to buy toxic bank assets, but the private equity executive said the approach offers other investors a good opportunity to make money, Reuters reported.

headline: Cuban Seeks to Have S.E.C. Charges Dismissed
abstract: Mark Cuban, the billionaire who has being sued by the Securities and Exchange Commission for insider trading, asked a federal court to dismiss the charges, contending that the regulator was trying to “impermissibly expand the scope of liability.”

headline: Chief of Independent News and Media to Resign
abstract: Anthony O’Reilly, chief of Independent News and Media, a Dublin publisher that owns The Independent of London, said Friday that he would step down as the company moved to end a dispute with an investor, The New York Times’s Eric Pfanner reports.

headline: A Miller’s Tale, a Widow’s Tale, a Beggar’s Tale….
abstract: The journey to Karbala is a chance for pilgrims to congregate, share stories and make new friendships. For traders it is an opportunity to hawk their wares along the way and for single men and women it may be a rare chance for a romantic dalliance.

headline: An Author’s Pitch for New Directors of Citigroup
abstract: It will be a thankless job, but someone has to do it: At least six new board members are needed for Citigroup.

headline: ‘John Mayer Has a TV Show’ Again, Almost
abstract: “CBS is close to a deal with pop star John Mayer for a music and variety TV show,” the network confirmed Wednesday.

headline: S.E.C. May Consider Reinstating Uptick Rule
abstract: Federal regulators said Tuesday that they would consider reviving the uptick restriction on short sellers of stocks, Reuters reported.

headline: Dow’s Chief Says Rohm Deal Is Still On
abstract: Dow Chemical‘s chief executive told CNBC on Tuesday that the chemical giant is very sorry that it can’t close its $15 billion merger with Rohm & Haas right away. Furthermore, it understands why Rohm has now slapped it with a lawsuit in Delaware’s Court of Chancery, which would seek to force completion of the deal.

headline: Obama Is Expected to Meet With Top Bankers
abstract: President Obama is expected to meet with about a dozen top bankers on Friday, including the chief executives of JPMorgan Chase, Goldman Sachs and Citigroup.

headline: Ackman Seeks 5 Seats on Target’s Board
abstract: The activist hedge fund manager William A. Ackman said Monday that he would nominate himself and four others to the board of the discount chain Target.

headline: Wells Fargo Falls on Fears of Higher Losses
abstract: Wells Fargo shares fell on Wednesday to their lowest level in almost 12 years before recovering amid fears the fourth-largest U.S. bank could cut its dividend and post higher losses after its purchase of Wachovia.

headline: Rubin Is Stepping Down at Citigroup
abstract: Updated at 5:08 p.m.

headline: Obama’s Overture Leaves Iranians Uneasy
abstract: President Barack Obama’s willingness to talk to Iran seems to have put the Iranian leadership in an uncomfortable spot — both in Tehran and in Davos, Switzerland.

headline: Hands Steps Down as His Firm’s C.E.O.
abstract: Guy Hands is giving up day-to-day control of his private equity firm, Terra Firma Capital Partners, in order to focus on the firm’s investment portfolio, which includes the troubled music group EMI.

headline: Buzz Media Hooks $12.5 Million
abstract: Buzz Media, the social media network formerly known as Buzznet, has nabbed $12.5 million in a fresh round of funding.

headline: Gap Joins the Billion-Dollar Online Sales Club
abstract: Gap, the casual-apparel retailer, surpassed $1 billion in annual online sales for the first time, partly by linking its disparate brands on a single Web platform.

headline: Who’s Really Being Propped Up in the A.I.G. Bailout?
abstract: The counterparties — whoever they are — may be the real beneficiaries of the taxpayers’ growing commitment.

headline: Cuomo’s Battle for Bonus Disclosure Sets Off Debate
abstract: Andrew M. Cuomo is starting to unearth some of the most closely guarded secrets on Wall Street: the identities of Merrill Lynch employees who collected large bonuses even as the brokerage firm lost billions of dollars, The New York Times’s Louise Story writes.

headline: BofA May Be Next, Credit Analysts Say
abstract: Update | 3:00 p.m. With Citigroup‘s third government bailout revealed, Wall Street is pondering Bank on America‘s fate.

headline: Moody’s Sees Cracks in Barclays’ Armor
abstract: Barclays may be projecting confidence these days, but the debt-watchers at Moody’s are taking a much more cautious tone.

headline: For High Earners, Day of Reckoning With Taxman
abstract: This is the season of the scam, from Bernie Madoff to Stanford Financial with a clutch of smaller swindles in between. What hasn’t received as much attention are the personal Ponzi schemes that are about to come crashing down, The New York Times’s Paul Sullivan reports. These involve the people who calculated ways to delay their tax payments.

headline: Carbonite Stacks the Deck on Amazon
abstract: The online-backup service has reviews on Amazon written by full-time employees.

headline: Union Group Seeks Ouster of BofA Chief
abstract: A group that works with union pension funds called for the ouster of Bank of America Chairman and Chief Executive Kenneth D. Lewis, citing the bank’s falling stock price and damage from its acquisition of Merrill Lynch.

headline: OneSpot Raises $4.2 Million
abstract: OneSpot, a company that helps Web sites offer links to relevant news stories elsewhere on the Internet, has raised $4.2 million in a first round of venture funding, VentureBeat reports.

headline: Got a Question? Ask K.G.B. Agents for the Answer
abstract: It’s not quite the Soviet K.G.B., but a new service called kgb uses human agents to answer texted questions from mobile users for 50 cents a pop.

headline: Receivables Exchange Raises $7.75 Million
abstract: The Receivables Exchange, a New Orleans company that runs an online marketplace for real-time trading of accounts receivable, has closed a $7.75 million financing round through Redpoint Ventures, with reinvestment from Prism Ventureworks.

headline: Painting Lawns Green
abstract: A California city has hired a contractor to paint the lawns of distressed homes green.

headline: London Paper Tries to Decipher a Russian Owner
abstract: Evgeny Lebedev, the 28-year-old son of the K.G.B. agent turned oligarch Aleksandr Y. Lebedev and the new senior executive director of a London daily, The Evening Standard, took other senior editors from the paper out for lunch recently.

headline: Citigroup Sees $1.4 Billion Charge Over LyondellBasell
abstract: Citigroup expects to take a $1.4 billion pre-tax charge in its just-completed fourth quarter related to its exposure to LyondellBasell, the world’s third-largest petrochemical company, whose U.S. operations filed for bankruptcy protection this week.

headline: Ford Confirms Talks With Potential Volvo Buyers
abstract: The Ford Motor Company is in talks with several potential buyers of its Swedish unit, Volvo, a company spokesman said Wednesday.

headline: Harrah’s Swap to Include $2.8 Billion in New Notes
abstract: The privately held casino operator Harrah’s Entertainment wants to exchange an unspecified amount of debt for up to $2.8 billion worth of new notes in order to lower its debt obligations and have more time to pay back lenders, The Associated Press said.

headline: R.B.S. Bids Goodbye to Leveraged Lending
abstract: For private equity firms hoping to get hard-to-find financing for deals, there’s one less place for them to turn.

headline: The Return of the Dissenters
abstract: Signs of change at the S.E.C.

headline: New season, new address for this F1 blog
abstract: The coming F1 season – less than two weeks away – will be the fourth in the life of this blog, and I am really delighted to announce that the blog will be moving from the IHT site to the New York Times site. Same blog, different address, but the whole archive of the blog moves along with it, so if you have any favorite comments you posted within the last three years and you want to show them to your children and grand children, you can still do so. (Same applies to all my previous posts, of course.) I do not plan to change anything in my approach to the blog either, so if you like what I do, you should find the same thing on the NYT site.

headline: Fed Lent Less to Financial Firms in Latest Week
abstract: The Federal Reserve made fewer direct loans to banks and financial companies at the discount window in the latest week, resuming the trend of recent declines, Fed data showed on Thursday.

abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has quietly backed away from a rule that had allowed the accounting firm that audited Bernard L. Madoff Investment Securities to avoid oversight by a regulator that was created after the Enron and WorldCom scandals, The New York Times’s Floyd Norris reported.

abstract: Some of the nation’s large banks, according to economists and other finance experts, are like dead men walking, The New York Times’s Steve Lohr reports.

abstract: The nation’s number-two tech retailer is seeking court approval to shut down, says our blog-cousin DealBook.

headline: A Sign of the Times: A.I.G. Sues Countrywide
abstract: American International Group has become a national symbol of how betting on risky mortgages can go horribly wrong. Countrywide Financial was one of the biggest producers of risky mortgages. Now, the two icons of the financial meltdown may be facing off in court.

headline: Super Return: Leon Black and the Great Delevering
abstract: Leon Black, founding partner of Apollo Management, was called the “king of distressed debt” here at the Super Return conference in Berlin.

headline: Does Broadband Need a Stimulus?
abstract: Cable lines that already pass near most U.S. homes will soon be capable of providing ultra-fast Internet service — without any government subsidies.

headline: Wilbur Ross Sees Up to 800 More Bank Failures
abstract: The billionaire investor Wilbur Ross, who earned a fortune buying up distressed companies, predicted Thursday that as many as 800 more banks in the United States would fail in the next few years.

headline: Dimon: A Little Less Talking, a Little More Action, Please
abstract: JPMorgan Chase‘s Jamie Dimon apparently wants one thing and one thing alone: for regulators and legislators to stop jawboning and come up with a solution to the banking industry’s problem.

headline: Icahn May Seek Board Changes at Lions Gate
abstract: Carl C. Icahn has once again raised his stake in Lions Gate Entertainment and said he may seek to make changes to the film studio’s board.

headline: Merkin Asks Judge to Modify Order in Madoff Case
abstract: Lawyers for the financier J. Ezra Merkin have asked a judge to modify a temporary restraining order that is restricting Mr. Merkin’s Ariel Fund from recouping losses it suffered from its investment with Bernard L. Madoff, who is accused of running a $50 billion Ponzi scheme.

headline: MSNBC In Talks With Radio Host Ed Schultz
abstract: MSNBC is in talks with Ed Schultz, the progressive radio talk show host, about a permanent position at the cable news channel.

headline: E-Book Seller Fictionwise Bought by Barnes & Noble
abstract: The online e-book seller was purchased by the bookstore operator for $15.7 million.

headline: The Week That Deals (Almost) Dried Up
abstract: Deals aren’t dead — just ask Pfizer or Live Nation — but they did seem to go into a coma last week.

headline: A.I.G. to Pay Big Bonuses, Setting Off Criticism
abstract: The American International Group, which has received more than $170 billion in taxpayer bailout money from the Treasury and Federal Reserve, plans to pay about $165 million in bonuses by Sunday to executives in the same business unit that brought the company to the brink of collapse last year.

headline: Live-Blogging the House Hearing on A.I.G.
abstract: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner and Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, were the star witnesses on Capitol Hill on Tuesday as Congress continues to examine the government’s bailout and oversight of the American International Group (and, of course, those bonuses).

headline: Prosecutors Try Again to Put Madoff in Jail
abstract: Federal prosecutors remain determined to put the disgraced financier Bernard L. Madoff in jail ahead of a trial for fraud.

headline: Foreclosing on Skyscrapers
abstract: An industry group announces that “the number and height of tall buildings completed in 2008 was greater than any other year in history.”

headline: Chrysler Gets Interest in Viper Brand
abstract: Chrysler apparently has three potential bidders for its Dodge Viper brand, which the struggling automaker put on the block last summer.

headline: Fallon Gets a Ratings Boost on Day One
abstract: Jimmy Fallon’s first appearance as host of the “Late Night” franchise on NBC attracted the show’s highest ratings on a Monday in more than three years, at least according to Nielsen’s preliminary estimates.

headline: Ross Praises U.S. Stance With Automakers
abstract: Washington is taking a tough stance with General Motors and Chrysler, and that is just fine with Wilbur Ross.

headline: Dow Imperiled by Its Deal for Rohm & Haas
abstract: To utter something along the lines that maybe, just maybe, deals that stop making sense ought to be called off, or at least rejiggered, especially in the middle of a once-in-a-lifetime financial crisis, invites withering scorn, especially if you say it to someone on Wall Street or in the legal profession.

headline: R.B.S. Seeks to Unwind a Decade of Deals
abstract: Royal Bank of Scotland is retrenching to its core businesses and plans to leave as many as 36 countries, but undoing a decade of deals in the eye of a financial storm will be a long process, Reuters writes.

headline: Genes Control Your Stock Picks (and Other Research)
abstract: In honor of some recent gains in the stock market, a few stock-related studies.

headline: Police Think Fund Manager Planned to Vanish
abstract: A missing hedge fund manager who owed investors a $50 million payout told his wife in a note he felt guilty about mismanaging people’s money, and threatened to kill himself, according to a sheriff’s report released Tuesday.

headline: Coming to America – Expectations
abstract: I don’t know what I’m going to face in America. All of my opinions about America, and American universities, do not come from people who have been there or from people who have lived that life. They just come from watching movies.

headline: A.I.G. Bonuses Strike a Nerve on the Internet
abstract: Some people are vengeful, calling for jail, public humiliation or even revolution over the decision by the American International Group to award $165 million in bonuses to employees who were in part responsible for the insurance giant’s near collapse — though few go as far as Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, who has suggested that company executives should “resign or go commit suicide.”

headline: If You Got Money, It’s Time to Spend Some
abstract: Americans who borrowed too much should certainly cut back, but for those with cash in their bank accounts, this is the time to spend.

headline: And So Begins the Next Mainframe Saga
abstract: Cisco’s coming server product could stand as the first of a new type of computer system that forces customers to rethink their data centers.

headline: TPG Scales Back Distressed Fund, Report Says
abstract: Even as rival private equity firms raise fresh funds to invest in distressed financial assets, TPG is scaling back the $6 billion fund it raised for that purpose, The Financial Times reported.

headline: BATS Exchange Ranks 3rd Behind N.Y.S.E. and Nasdaq
abstract: BATS Exchange, the stock market that went live on Nov. 6, said it ranks as the world’s third-largest securities exchange, behind only the New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq Stock Market.

headline: Supply, Demand and Executive Pay
abstract: An economist explains why his colleagues are wrong to justify high executive-compensation levels.

abstract: The camera has the most powerful lens you can get on a point-and-shoot.

headline: Q & A: Mini-Movies by E-mail
abstract: Video files too big to email? Try running through some video-editing software to cut it down to size.

headline: As Dollar Shrinks, Oil Rises Above $50
abstract: The Federal Reserve’s decision to fire up the printing presses and buy $1 trillion in debt continued to wash over world financial markets on Thursday, dragging down the value of the dollar and pushing the prices of oil and gold higher.

headline: Citi Canceled Trip, But Gave Gift Cards Instead
abstract: Citigroup, the beleaguered and bailed-out banking giant, is again drawing attention for its corporate perks.

headline: Patent King I.B.M. Will Give Away More Ideas
abstract: While securing more patents than ever, I.B.M. pledges to make thousands of inventions per year freely available to boost technical innovation.

abstract: A new BlueGene system from I.B.M. set for delivery in 2012 could be the fastest computer ever made.

abstract: How did B. Ramalinga Raju, the chairman of one of India’s largest information technology companies, carry out the biggest financial fraud in this country’s history? Apparently it does take a village.

headline: Carlyle Raises $500 Million for Mideast Fund
abstract: The Carlyle Group said Monday that it has raised $500 million for its first Middle East and North Africa private equity fund.

headline: New Polaroid Camera Revives Instant Prints
abstract: The Polaroid film cameras may be dead, but you can still have instant photos with the company’s new PoGo Instant Digital Camera, a compact snapshooter with a built-in printer that lets you capture and immediately print 2-by-3-inch images.

headline: Citi Is Urged to Replace Its Chairman
abstract: Federal banking regulators are pressing Citigroup to shake up its board and replace its chairman, Winfried F. W. Bischoff, in an effort to restore confidence in the beleaguered financial giant, The New York Times’s Eric Dash reported.

headline: The Roadster Points the Way for Tesla
abstract: Take a sports car, add a dollop of Bruce Wayne and a generous helping of James Bond, and you might have an idea what it’s like to drive the Tesla Roadster.

headline: Town Mourns Typical Businessman Who Took Untypical Risks
abstract: When the body of Adolf Merckle was discovered on the railroad tracks here last week, authorities ruled the German billionaire’s death to be a suicide.

headline: Markets Close on a Down Note
abstract: Losses in consumer stocks dragged Wall Street lower on Wednesday, while Bank of America stock fell below $5 a share, signaling more rough months ahead for the country’s largest financial institutions.

headline: Conseco Plunges as Auditors Raise Concerns
abstract: Shares of Conseco dropped more than 50 percent on Monday after the insurance company said it needed to provide its auditors with more information about “the company’s ability to continue as a going concern.”

headline: Rattner to Serve as Lead Adviser on Auto Bailout
abstract: Steven Rattner, the private equity executive, will join the Treasury Department as a lead adviser to Secretary Timothy F. Geithner on auto industry issues. DealBook has also obtained info on Quadrangle’s management of Mayor Bloomberg’s blind trust and an e-mail from Mr. Rattner to friends.

headline: As Week Ends, Shares Manage to Stay on Upside
abstract: Wall Street closed higher for the fourth consecutive day on Friday, capping its best week since November, and one that gave investors a break from a relentless streak of declines, The New York Times’s Jack Healy reports.

headline: Hedge Funds Said to Target Australian Banks
abstract: Australian regulators are feeling increased pressure to renew a short-selling ban amid speculation that foreign hedge funds are gearing up to bet against the share prices of the nation’s four largest banks, The Sydney Morning Herald reported.

headline: Ratings: A Five-Year High for ‘The Bachelor’
abstract: ABC dominated the night thanks to the most watched finale of “The Bachelor” in over five years, averaging 15.5 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., and the highest rated “After the Final Rose” special ever with 17.5 million at 10 p.m.

headline: Kuwaiti Fund Would Reconsider Dow Deal, Report Says
abstract: Could the Kuwait Investment Authority unstick Dow Chemical‘s disputed takeover of Rohm & Haas?

headline: Quadrangle Enlists Team for Bloomberg’s Money
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s fortune is getting some new management. The Quadrangle Group, the firm picked by Mr. Bloomberg last year to invest his billions in a blind trust while he is New York’s mayor, announced Monday that it had hired three heavy-hitting money managers.

headline: Sam Zell’s Former Empire, Underwater in a Big Way
abstract: It was, for a brief shining moment, the real estate deal of the century.

abstract: Tronox is ready to become the latest chemical maker to file for bankruptcy, as the Oklahoma-based company is set to seek Chapter 11 protection as soon as Sunday night.

headline: Chrysler Financial to Get $1.5 Billion U.S. Loan
abstract: The Treasury Department said Friday that it would lend Chrysler‘s finance arm $1.5 billion to help it make new car loans as part of a broader program to revive the sputtering domestic auto industry.

headline: Apollo Said to Name Wall Street Veteran as Operating Officer
abstract: Apollo Management has tapped Henry Silverman, the financier who is a longtime friend of the private equity firm’s chief, Leon Black, as chief operating officer, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing unidentified sources.

headline: Asian Stocks Gain as U.S. Bails Out Bank
abstract: Asian stock markets rebounded Friday from the previous day’s rout, with Tokyo’s index gaining nearly 3 percent, as the U.S. bailed out Bank of America again and a weaker yen lifted exporters like Toyota Motor. Major European markets also opened higher.

headline: Davos in the Media: No-Shows, Sovereign Funds
abstract: This year, the talk emanating from the World Economic Forum, in Davos, Switzerland, has so far been focused on how little star-power the gabfest is generating this year.

abstract: Fox is setting up post-“American Idol” previews for two new shows.

abstract: A number of cash-starved private equity firms are putting their assets on the block, creating a potentially lucrative deal-making market for firms that specialize in secondary buyouts, The Wall Street Journal reported.

abstract: Google cut 100 of its 20,000 employees. All of them are recruiters no longer needed since the company slowed its hiring.

abstract: Tuesday afternoon’s news that Dr. Sanjay Gupta is being considered for the position of surgeon general took many by surprise, even within CNN, where he has worked since 2001.

Now, TiVo is raising a new alarm – one that reflects a big change in its own business model.

Mulally, the chief executive of Ford Motor Company, was very clear on one point: “It’s not our plan at all to access the government’s money,” he said. In doing so, he continued to draw a line between Ford and its rivals, General Motors and Chrysler, both of which have taken government-backed loans to avoid having to file for bankruptcy protection.

abstract: Carl C. Icahn, it seems, is not at all happy with fellow activist investor Warren Lichtenstein.
