headline: Leverage Gets a Makeover in Obama Plan
abstract: The world “leveraged” has been used to vilify investment banks and other financial institutions that borrowed to the hilt, but on Monday, the Treasury department invoked the word repeatedly as a force for economic good.

headline: MGM Mirage’s City Center Hires Bankruptcy Counsel
abstract: CityCenter, the troubled residential and casino development in Las Vegas, has hired a law firm, Dewey & LeBoeuf, to prepare for a potential bankruptcy filing, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Thursday.

headline: Twitter Raises $35 Million
abstract: Twitter, the popular microblogging service, raised money from two West Coast venture firms, Benchmark Capital and Institutional Venture Partners.

headline: Man Sues for Refund After Buying Out Madoff Account From Ex-Wife
abstract: To the list of things Bernard L. Madoff has been blamed for ruining — retirements, lives, reputations — add another: a clean breakup, The New York Times’s John Eligon writes.

headline: Breaking Up a Must for Citi
abstract: Any physician would agree that amputating a healthy arm or leg is unlikely to be an effective cure for heart disease.

headline: Surge in Bullish Bets Ahead of Schering Deal
abstract: Most people learned of Merck‘s $41 billion bid for Schering-Plough on Monday morning. But did anyone have more than an inkling last week that the deal was in the works?

headline: Curious at Amazon, but Not Idle
abstract: Jeff Bezos spent last week working eight-hour shifts in an Amazon.com warehouse. Among chief executives, he is distinguished by his curiosity

headline: Even Lacking Lula, Brazil’s Delegation Struts
abstract: Brazil is walking tall in Davos.

headline: The Inspiration for Seinfeld’s ‘Marriage Ref’
abstract: Jerry Seinfeld is coming back to NBC as the producer of a prime-time reality series called “The Marriage Refs.”

headline: The Last Days of the Oligarchs?
abstract: They are larger-than-life figures at home and abroad, men who saw themselves as the Carnegies or Rockefellers of Russia. They are known as oligarchs, and they may soon be thrown into the dustbin of history by the economic crisis, The New York Times’s Andrew E. Kramer writes.

headline: RBC Capital Hires Private Equity Banker
abstract: A former private-equity banker from JPMorgan Chase, John Sorice, has joined RBC Capital Markets, where he becomes a managing director in the firm’s United States financial sponsors group.

headline: Madoff Agrees to Give Up Property, Art, Tickets
abstract: Bernard L. Madoff has agreed to give up the rights to his disgraced investment business and his company’s prized artwork and entertainment tickets, as an official for a group providing relief to investors said Tuesday that some checks may be in the mail this month, The Associated Press reported.

headline: The Obsession With Twitter’s Business Model
abstract: A new ad campaign will bring in some money for Twitter, but despite the hype, it is not the business model that Twitter watchers breathlessly await.

headline: Dial-a-Mattress, in Bankruptcy, Plans Sale to a Rival
abstract: Dial-a-Mattress Operating Corporation, the company that initiated telephone sales of bedding with its 1-800-Mattres jingles, has filed for bankruptcy protection and plans to sell the business to its rival, Sleepy’s.

headline: A Lucrative I.P.O., Too Hot to Handle
abstract: Here’s a shocker: Wall Street doesn’t appear all that excited by pornography.

headline: Banking Plan Propels Wall St. to Best Day in Months
abstract: Details of the government’s plans to clean up the nation’s banks ignited a blazing stock market rally on Monday, lifting Wall Street to its best one-day performance in five months and tempting some investors to imagine what they would not have dared just a few weeks ago — that the worst may finally be over.

headline: Peering Deeper Into the Picture
abstract: How to access embedded data in a digital photograph.

headline: I.B.M., Looking to Buy Sun, Sets Up a Software Strategy
abstract: I.B.M.’s interest in acquiring the server computer maker Sun Microsystems for nearly $7 billion may seem at first to be a reversal of its recent efforts to move away from the hardware business.

headline: House Votes to Delay Switch to Digital TV
abstract: Television owners appear to have four more months to upgrade their old sets before they are rendered obsolete.

headline: Afghanistan and Iraq – What If?
abstract: More than any other factor, it is the American invasion of Iraq that looms over Afghanistan and all of its dashed hopes.

headline: Gulf Sovereign Funds Said to Have Lost Big
abstract: A new report indicates investment losses left Gulf Arab government funds more than $80 billion poorer last year despite the windfall from record oil prices, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Asian Stocks Rise on Reports of Greater U.S. Stake in Citigroup
abstract: Asian stocks rose and the U.S. dollar tumbled on Monday after a report said the U.S. government could end up owning as much as 40 percent of Citigroup, helping alleviate some of the uncertainty surrounding the future of U.S. banks.

headline: Blagojevich on ‘The Late Show’
abstract: The showman Rod R. Blagojevich, former governor of Illinois, is on a second media tour.

headline: Icahn Group to Bid for Tropicana Casino
abstract: A group including the billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn says it plans to bid for the troubled Tropicana Casino and Resort in Atlantic City in a bankruptcy court auction.

headline: Lawrence Summers on the Crisis
abstract: Lawrence Summers, President Obama’s top economics adviser, said this morning that he saw early signs that the economic crisis was beginning to ease. But he emphasized that the crisis would not end anytime soon.

headline: Stocks Slip in Europe and Asia
abstract: Stocks fell Wednesday in Asia and Europe amid concern for the health of the financial system, The New York Times’s David Jolly and Bettina Wassener reported.

headline: Playboy Open to Possible Sale or Strategic Changes
abstract: Playboy magazine may be up for sale — and not just by the copy.

headline: Senator Skeptical About Loaning $30 Billion to G.M.
abstract: Borrowing $30 billion from taxpayers to finance its restructuring could weigh General Motors down too much for the company to be viable, an outspoken senator who voted against aid for automakers said Wednesday, The New York Times’s Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley report from Detroit.

headline: Morgan Stanley and G.E. Seek Tax Waiver on Loans
abstract: Morgan Stanley, United Technologies and General Electric are asking Congress to waive tax penalties on businesses that borrow from their offshore units, Congressional aides and lobbyists told Bloomberg News.

headline: Greenhill Hires Senior Adviser for Technology
abstract: Greenhill & Company, the boutique investment bank, said on Tuesday that it had hired a longtime veteran of several technology companies as a senior adviser to the firm.

headline: Major Fortis Shareholder to Vote Against BNP Deal
abstract: Ping An Insurance, facing a 92 percent decline in the value of its investment in Fortis, said Sunday it would reject the state-organized breakup plan for the Belgian financial services company.

headline: Iceland’s Baugur Loses Much of its British Empire
abstract: Baugur Group, an Icelandic investor, ceded control of its holdings in several major British retailers Friday after the main creditor of its British subsidiary, Landsbanki Islands, succeeded in having the unit placed into a form of bankruptcy reorganization.

headline: Out. Now What?
abstract: Despite never having been charged with a crime and losing a year of his life while he waited for the Americans to conclude he should no longer be held, he expresses surprisingly little rancor towards his jailers

headline: Dow Gets EU Approval for Rohm & Haas Deal
abstract: Dow Chemical, the biggest U.S. chemical maker, got the green light from European regulators for its $15. 4 billion takeover of Rohm & Haas.

headline: UBS Adds Financial Institutions Bankers
abstract: UBS said its investment banking department hired two new managing directors for its financial institutions group.

headline: Barclays to Buy Specialist Firm From JPMorgan
abstract: Barclays agreed Monday to acquire Bear Wagner Specialists from JPMorgan Chase in a move that will leave the New York Stock Exchange with five designated market makers.

headline: Separation Rule Is Not the Answer
abstract: Why would anybody run a casino and a utility under the same roof?

headline: When Will the Good Times Return?
abstract: Alibaba’s Jack Ma thinks the recession is going to last a long time. But he says Chinese factories can help American entrepreneurs.

headline: Aster Data Raises $12 Million
abstract: Aster Data Systems, which stores data for social networking site MySpace and others, has raised $12 million in a second round of venture funding, VentureBeat reported.

headline: Global Sports Forum: Formula One Edition
abstract: PART THREE: THE TEAMS

headline: Panasonic Goes Wide With 25mm Lenses
abstract: Panasonic’s new digital cameras offer ultra-wide-angle lenses.

headline: JHL Capital Reports Gains of Up to 18%
abstract: John Paulson isn’t the only hedge fund manager to come out of 2008 with big profits. The Chicago-based JHL Capital Group, a small firm run by James H. Litinsky, chalked up gains of 17.1 percent to 18 percent net of fees last year despite the global stock market meltdown, according to a letter the firm sent to clients on Tuesday.

headline: Another View: Advice on Lawyers for Madoff Victims
abstract: Eric M. Rosenberg, an attorney and president of LitigationProofing, a firm that helps companies limit exposure to potential lawsuits, offers this view of what Bernard L. Madoff’s investors should consider when they are choosing lawyers to seek recovery of their money:

headline: New SDXC Memory Cards to Hit 2 Terabytes
abstract: New XDSC memory cards will offer 2 terabytes of storage.

headline: Adding Up A.I.G.’s Backdoor Bailouts
abstract: Of the $170 billion in government funds used to prop up American International Group, a large chunk has gone to buy soured securities — at full price — from big banks like Goldman Sachs.

headline: After Madoff, Regulatory Oversight of Auditors Is Back
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has quietly backed away from a rule that had allowed the accounting firm that audited Bernard L. Madoff Investment Securities to avoid oversight by a regulator that was created after the Enron and WorldCom scandals, The New York Times’s Floyd Norris reported.

headline: Solvency of Big Banks Is Questioned
abstract: Some of the nation’s large banks, according to economists and other finance experts, are like dead men walking, The New York Times’s Steve Lohr reports.

headline: Dr.  Doom Finds Promise in Obama’s Toxic-Asset Plan
abstract: Nouriel Roubini, a/k/a “Dr. Doom,” is giving the Obama administration’s new plan to buy toxic assets the thumbs up.

headline: From DealBook: Circuit City to Liquidate
abstract: The nation’s number-two tech retailer is seeking court approval to shut down, says our blog-cousin DealBook.

headline: A Laptop That’s Bulked Up
abstract: Asus’s new widescreen laptop is anything but portable.

headline: Big Win in Delaware for Corporate Boards
abstract: On Tuesday, Chancellor William B. Chandler III dismissed all but one of the claims in a shareholder suit in the Delaware Chancery Court against the board of Citigroup. The shareholders principally alleged that the Citi board had breached their fiduciary duties by allowing the company to invest in, and sustain significant losses in, the subprime lending market.

headline: Germany’s WestLB Plans Auction
abstract: German state-owned bank WestLB said Thursday that it was looking to sell itself off in an auction process after repeated efforts to merge with other financial institutions were ruled out amid the continuing financial crisis.

headline: Exelon Claims 46% of NRG Shares in Hostile Tender Offer
abstract: The battle between Exelon and NRG heated up on Wednesday, after Exelon said that it has garnered nearly 46 percent of its fellow power company’s stock through a hostile tender offer.

headline: Coming to America
abstract: Many of my colleagues who want to go to the States are wondering about their futures there, especially after the problems with the economy.

headline: The Nation’s New Chief Information Officer Speaks
abstract: Vivek Kundra, the new federal chief information officer, wants to bring the latest technological trends, from smart phones to cloud computing, to the federal government.

headline: Nasdaq Eyes European Deal
abstract: Nasdaq OMX plans to acquire an alternative trading platform in Europe, the U.S.-based group said on Thursday.

headline: Amid Hits to Industry, Owl Creek Says It’s OK
abstract: While some hedge fund managers have been left apologizing for their performance last year, those who lost less than 10 percent are breathing a sigh of relief.

headline: Madoff’s Wife Seeks Shelter in Florida Home
abstract: The wife of the admitted swindler Bernard L. Madoff has declared her estate in Palm Beach, Fla., as her primary residence, in a move that may shield the $9.4 million home from creditors.

headline: H.P.’s Hunk of Burning Light
abstract: Hewlett-Packard is developing a new generation of optical components that could make computers thousands of times faster.

headline: Parsing Pandit: How Soon Is Now?
abstract: Citigroup is back in the vortex, and suddenly its chief executive, Vikram Pandit, is in a hurry to get some news out the door. Jack Flack parses his memo to employees.

headline: Lawmakers Challenge Bankers on Bailout
abstract: Eight of the nation’s top bankers faced off Wednesday against critical lawmakers in Congress, who questioned their use of tens of billions of dollars of taxpayer money and pointed out the growing public anger at the banks in the bailout, The New York Times’s Louise Story reports from Washington.

headline: European Airlines May Push for U.S. Deals
abstract: Last year, the Open Skies Treaty between the U.S. and European Union opened new routes across the Atlantic, in what was seen mainly as a win for U.S. airlines wanting access to European hubs.

headline: Another View: Curbing ‘Mobocracy’ With Competence
abstract: Jeffrey Sonnenfeld, senior associate dean of the Yale School of Management, offers this view of the Obama administration’s role in the bonus uproar. Update on March 26: Mr. Sonnenfeld posted a reply addressing many of the comments on this post.

headline: Carlyle Group Offers Cash to IMO Carwash Creditors
abstract: The Carlyle Group has offered to pay $36 million to keep control of IMO Carwash, in return for the company’s creditors writing off debt, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Oil Tycoon Seeks Gaylord Board Seats
abstract: The Texas oil billionaire Robert B. Rowling nominated himself and three other candidates to the board of the hotel operator Gaylord Entertainment on Wednesday, following through with a promise he made earlier this month in a letter sharply criticizing the company.

headline: NRG Blasts Exelon Bid as Deadline Approaches
abstract: NRG Energy is stepping up its efforts to fend off a hostile takeover attempt from Exelon, a rival power operator, ahead of next week’s deadline for NRG shareholders to tender their stock.

headline: Pershing Fund Lets Investors Withdraw
abstract: In a move that could force similar changes at other money-losing hedge funds, the well-known fund manager William A. Ackman is cutting his fees and allowing investors to take what is left of their money from one of the funds he manages, The New York Times’s Zachery Kouwe reported.

headline: A.I.G. Smackdown: Liddy vs. Greenberg
abstract: Edward M. Liddy, the chief executive of the American International Group, clashed Monday with his predecessor, Maurice R. Greenberg.

headline: Former Chief of Autodesk Takes Reins at Yahoo
abstract: In tapping Carol Bartz as Yahoo’s new chief executive on Tuesday, the company’s board has selected a seasoned manager and tough-minded technology executive who established Autodesk, the maker of design software, as a market leader and successfully steered it through a boom and bust cycle, The New York Times’s Miguel Helft writes.

headline: For Paulson, $1.5 Billion on the Line in Dow Deal
abstract: Just how much is Dow Chemical‘s deal for Rohm & Haas worth to John Paulson?

headline: Ford Moves to Restructure Its Debt
abstract: The Ford Motor Company said Wednesday afternoon that it intended to eliminate as much as $10.4 billion in debt by giving cash and shares of its stock to creditors, The New York Times’s Nick Bunkley and Bill Vlasic reported from Detroit.

headline: Professors Come to Cuban’s Defense
abstract: Mark Cuban has lined up a roster of Ivy League professors to take his part in his battle against the Securities and Exchange Commission, which has accused the investor of trading on insider information.

headline: Did Madoff Trade Any Stocks? Evidence Is Lacking
abstract: The disgraced financier Bernard L. Madoff, accused of securities fraud, appears to have been running a pure Ponzi scheme because industry regulators have been unable to find evidence of any actual stock trades.

headline: Are Those Bank Assets Really So Toxic?
abstract: Richard X. Bove, the banking analyst, argues that New York Times columnist Paul Krugman and others are overstating the amount of unrecognized losses lurking on banks’ balance sheets.

headline: Tensions Flare in Philadelphia Newspapers Bankruptcy
abstract: The case of Philadelphia Newspapers, the company that owns The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Philadelphia Daily News, appears to be quickly turning into a brawl.

headline: Senators Seek More Funds to Fight Financial Fraud
abstract: Charles E. Schumer, the Democratic senator from New York, and Richard Shelby, a Republican senator from Alabama, are expected to introduce new spending legislation on Thursday designed to beef up enforcement and detection of white-collar crime in the wake of the $50 billion fraud allegedly perpetrated by Bernard L. Madoff.

headline: Ratings: ‘Dancing’ Draws 11 Million to ‘Castle’
abstract: Week two of “Dancing With the Stars” remained dominant in the ratings on Monday, garnering 21.1 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: It’s the Regulations, Not the Regulator
abstract: It has become a truism of the financial crisis that the system was prone to collapse because there was no single regulator who had the legal tools and authority to prevent a meltdown. That belief has led to calls from some lawmakers and major banks, among others, for a new “systemic risk regulator” — one regulator to monitor the entire financial landscape for problems that could lead to cascading failures, The New York Times’s editorial board writes.

headline: A Few New Ideas to Help Tim Geithner
abstract: Some ideas about how to price toxic assets and how to make a public-private partnership work on a “bad bank.”

headline: I’m Just a Cockeyed Optimist
abstract: Taking a second look at the Geithner plan for toxic assets.

headline: Blocks of Stock, Hard to Unload
abstract: Block trades are back.

headline: A Little Late, and Meaningless, Too
abstract: Accounting firms that audit broker-dealers will now have to register with the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board. They were already required to do that by one section of the Sarbanes-Oxley law, which created the board, but the Securities and Exchange Commission waived that requirement for brokers that did not issue publicly traded securities.

headline: Despite Troubles, Tesla C.E.O. Promises Profitability This Year
abstract: Tesla chief Elon Musk says the troubled electric car start-up will be profitable this summer and step up its business selling batteries to other car companies.

headline: A Corporate Hero Admits Fraud
abstract: The winner of the “golden Peacock” award for corporate governance turns out to be a fraud.

headline: Alitalia Sells a Stake as It Makes Its Return
abstract: The Italian airline Alitalia agreed Monday to sell a minority stake to Air France-KLM, cementing ties with the airline just a day before Alitalia takes to the skies as a leaner, more cost-efficient airline, Caroline Brothers of The New York Times reported.

headline: Officials Knew About A.I.G. Bonuses Weeks Ago
abstract: The question was direct and prescient. Representative Joseph Crowley, Democrat of New York, asked the Treasury secretary in an open hearing what could be done to stop American International Group from paying $165 million in bonuses to hundreds of employees in the very unit that had nearly destroyed the company.

headline: Ex-Leaders of Countrywide Profit From Bad Loans
abstract: Fairly or not, Countrywide Financial and its top executives would be on most lists of those who share blame for the nation’s economic crisis. After all, the banking behemoth made risky loans to tens of thousands of Americans, helping set off a chain of events that has the economy staggering.

headline: New Toys for iThings
abstract: New accessories for dressing up your iStuff.

headline: Dreier Trustee Recovers $100 Million in Assets
abstract: An official appointed to recover the assets of Marc S. Dreier, the Manhattan lawyer accused of defrauding hedge funds of at least $400 million, says he has safeguarded more than $100 million in assets, including an $18.5 million yacht, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Time Warner Goes Over the Top
abstract: The head of Time Warner says the company will let people subscribe to its networks, like CNN and TNT, over the Internet without using a cable or satellite company.

headline: Electronics Companies Lose Big: Do You Win?
abstract: Consumer electronics companies post operating losses, putting added pressure on third-tier TV manufacturers.

headline: Citi-Morgan Talks May Spark Fresh Wave of Deals
abstract: The anticipated combination of brokerage units at Citigroup and Morgan Stanley is seen by analysts as the likely start of a fresh wave of consolidation in the troubled and thinning banking industry.

headline: S.E.C. Nominee Is Quizzed at Critical Time
abstract: President-elect Barack Obama’s choice to head the Securities and Exchange Commission goes before Congress on Thursday at a time when the embattled agency is being called on to help restore investor confidence shattered by the worst financial crisis in over 70 years, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Macquarie Hires Vice Chairman for Capital Advisors
abstract: The Macquarie Group, the Australian investment bank, continued a string of hires on Monday with the appointment of another former Lehman Brothers banker as the vice chairman of its Capital Advisors group.

headline: Live Blog: Iraq’s Provincial Elections
abstract: Check back for live updates on Iraq’s provincial elections.

headline: Fox Rothschild Takes Former Dreier Firm
abstract: Fox Rothschild said Thursday that it picked up Pastore Osterberg, a nine-lawyer firm hived off from Dreier L.L.C., the firm run by a lawyer charged with defrauding hedge funds.

headline: Venture Capital Pours $5.5 Million into Enclarity
abstract: Enclarity, a healthcare information technology start-up, has nabbed $5.5 million in a Series C round of funding, led by Ignition Partners and Bain Capital Ventures.

headline: $250 Billion Loss Possible in Banking Bailout
abstract: The government believes it could lose $250 billion, or a third, of the $750 billion it plans on using to buy troubled assets off bank balance sheets.

headline: Q & A: Taking a Security Test Drive
abstract: Some antivirus programs can wreak havoc with your PC. Here’s how to try some out before you spend money on one.

headline: Global Sports Forum: Formula One Edition
abstract: We’re back with our well-connected, seriously jet-lagged panel of F1 critics to talk about the 2009 season, which begins Sunday in Melbourne. A surprising number of people are talking down defending champion Lewis Hamilton in the buildup, but then it is a year of particular uncertainty with the technical changes and testing restrictions in the sport.

headline: Shares of Big Banks Skid Lower
abstract: Shares of Citigroup and Bank of America crashed through their previous 52-week lows on Friday, amid growing fears that the government might step in with a rescue plan that leaves the banks’ current shareholders with nothing.

headline: A First Look at Amazon’s Kindle App for the iPhone
abstract: Amazon.com’s new Kindle application for the Apple iPhone and iPod touch lacks key functionality, including an easy way to buy electronic books.

headline: Maker of Tomb Raider Agrees to $120 Million Deal
abstract: The maker of the Tomb Raider games has dodged financial peril through a bid from a major Japanese video game producer.

headline: Blockbuster Minus the Bricks and Mortar
abstract: Blockbuster joins the home stream for video on demand.

headline: In Wyeth, Pfizer Sees a Drug Pipeline
abstract: Molecules.

headline: The Smart Home Is Still Looking for a Market
abstract: The vision of the smart home has been around for decades. Yet consumers remain deeply skeptical about the technology.

headline: SXSW: Polling Guru Says Economy Could Drag Down Obama
abstract: Although President Obama’s popularity is high now, Nate Silver of FiveThirtyEight predicts that by next year, the public will be blaming the president for the economic slump.

headline: 3i Replaces Chief as Investments Fall
abstract: The chief executive of 3i, Philip Yea, has stepped down as the the publicly listed private equity firm has seen its value tumble. Mr. Yea will be succeeded by Michael Queen, who has worked at 3i for two decades, and most recently launched and ran the firm’s infrastructure arm.

headline: Stocks Fall Sharply in Asia and Europe
abstract: Stocks fell sharply in Europe and Asia on Monday, amid fears that the Group of 20 meeting this week would fail to come up with a plan to restart global growth and signs of chaos in the auto industry, The New York Times’s David Jolly and Bettina Wassener reported.

abstract: The nation’s number-two tech retailer is seeking court approval to shut down, says our blog-cousin DealBook.

headline: Deephaven Seeks to Spin Off Europe Fund, Report Says
abstract: Deephaven Capital Management, the hedge fund that has begun unwinding its operations, wants to spin off it’s London-based Deephaven European Event Fund, The Telegraph reported.

headline: Android Malware or Malicious Rumor?
abstract: An Android App rumored to damage phones presents a lesson on how unconfirmed reports spread.

headline: After Four Years, Energy Department Makes First ‘Green’ Loan
abstract: The U.S. Energy Department broke the logjam in its long-stalled alternative-energy loan program by awarding a $535 million guarantee to Solyndra, a Silicon Valley solar start-up.

headline: Ratings: A Thursday ‘Idol’ Lifts Fox
abstract: Fox won a rare first place finish in the ratings on Thursday thanks to the premiere of the fifth edition of “Hell’s Kitchen” and a special installment of “American Idol” on the night.

headline: For Pepsi-Cola, It’s Logo A Go-Go
abstract: The new logo for Pepsi-Cola that is appearing in television commercials — not to mention on cans, bottles, signs in stores and outdoor ads — is becoming almost as famous as the celebrities in the spots.

headline: Calm Judicial Eye in Storm Over Bail
abstract: The federal Magistrate Judge James C. Francis IV got a phone call Monday morning from a colleague on the bench, who teased him about a ruling he had made, which had made the front page of a legal publication.

headline: Texas Mogul in the Glare as Huge Fraud Is Alleged
abstract: In Texas, Robert Allen Stanford was just another wealthy financier.

headline: National Amusements Theater Auction Ignites Interest
abstract: Sumner Redstone’s National Amusements has received interest from strategic rivals and private equity firms for its American and British theater chains, Reuters reported, citing two sources with knowledge of the auction.

headline: The Supremes Will Decide Which Economics Makes Legal Sense
abstract: The Supreme Court will weigh in on a case that split the law in economics movement as it considers whether mutual fund shareholder can sue because his fund’s manager charges much higher fees to its captive fund than it does to institutional investors.

headline: Will U.S. Seek Ousters of Bank Chiefs?
abstract: With the Obama administration’s decision to push Rick Wagoner out from General Motors, some are wondering if executives at bailout-out banks may be next in line.

headline: Lawmakers Move to End Tax Break on Bank Deals
abstract: Lawmakers moved closer Thursday to overturning a recent change in Treasury Department policy, instituted under former Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., that permitted merging banks to reap billions of dollars in tax breaks.

headline: K.K.R. Hires Qantas Chairman as Senior Adviser
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said Monday that it has hired the chairman of Australian airline Qantas as a senior adviser to help bolster the private equity firm’s operations in that country.

headline: Big Blue’s Contrarian Manifesto
abstract: I.B.M. is optimistic because it thinks it is ideally positioned to be the general contract of choice for governments’ smart infrastructure projects.

headline: Where Are You? Show ‘Em With Google Latitude
abstract: Dodgeball may be dead, but Google is back with a new service, Latitude, that lets smartphone users share their whereabouts with their friends.

headline: A Computerized Personal Assistant for Twitter and Facebook
abstract: SocialToo is an online valet for your Twitter and Facebook accounts.

headline: Share and Store Data From One Box
abstract: Western Digital’s MyBook World Edition provides automatic backups and centralized storage.

headline: From Science: Google Earth Fills Its Watery Gaps
abstract: Information about the oceans will be the most significant of several upgrades to Google Earth.

headline: A Subdued Ad Market for the Academy Awards
abstract: It is estimated that ABC is charging about $1.4 million to $1.7 million for each 30 seconds of commercial time on the Academy Awards on Sunday, or as much as 20 percent less than last year.

headline: Dell Puts a Spicy Printer in Your Pocket
abstract: Dell launches a new pocket-size photo printer for photos on the go.

headline: Has the News Reached Armonk?
abstract: Is this the dumbest commercial ever from IBM?

headline: Stephen Schwarzman’s Maverick Proposal
abstract: The audacity of Stephen A. Schwarzman was not enough.

headline: Dark Days for the Deal Toy
abstract: Call them deal toys, Lucites or tombstones — by any name, these trinkets are experiencing a serious bear market.

headline: Former BHP Chief to Replace Head of Temasek
abstract: Ho Ching will step down as chief executive of the Singaporean state investor Temasek Holdings at a time when turmoil in global markets is ravaging the value of its investments.

headline: Live-Blogging the Senate’s Madoff Hearing
abstract: The Senate Banking Committee held a hearing on Tuesday to look into the disgraced financier Bernard L. Madoff’s reputed $50 billion Ponzi scheme, how it escaped detection for years and what regulatory changes are needed to prevent a repeat.

headline: By Slim Margin, Senate Advances Stimulus Bill
abstract: Senate Democrats on Monday advanced the $838 billion economic stimulus bill, clearing a major procedural hurdle by a razor-thin margin with the help of just three Republicans. Final passage of the bill is expected Tuesday.

headline: A Year-End Rally Vanishes

headline: Mexico: Kidnapping Episode Leaves 21 Dead
abstract: Soldiers in the state of Chihuahua chased and killed 14 armed men who had kidnapped nine people and killed six of them on Tuesday. One soldier was killed by the kidnappers, believed to be drug traffickers, bringing the death toll to 21. The gunmen took the hostages from the ranching town of Villa Ahumada and drove them to an isolated farm where six were killed, said Enrique Torres, a spokesman for the federal government’s antidrug operation in the state. A military convoy caught up with the kidnappers about 80 miles south of El Paso, killed seven of them and freed the remaining three hostages. Soldiers then pursued the other seven gunmen through heavy snow and killed them in a shootout.

headline: Correction
abstract: Because of an editing error, an obituary on June 17 about Tony Schwartz, a media consultant who helped create the “daisy ad” for Lyndon B. Johnson’s 1964 presidential campaign, envisioning a nuclear explosion, misstated the date of Mr. Schwartz’s death. It was Sunday, June 15 — not Saturday, June 14. A family member pointed out the error recently in an e-mail message.
